Article Title: Assessing Utility Where Short Measures Are Required: Development of the Short Assessment of Quality of Life-8 (AQoL-8) Instrument
Author Keywords: AQoL; cost-utility analysis; health-related quality of life; outcomes research
Keywords Plus: HEALTH-STATUS; OF-LIFE; SCALE ANALYSIS; EQ-5D; POPULATION; EUROQOL; RELIABILITY; VALUATIONS; STATES; TESTS
Abstract: Objectives: As researchers seek to include clinical outcomes, the health-related quality of life (HRQoL) of participants and meet economic evaluation demands, they are confronted with collecting disparate outcome data where parsimony is imperative. This study addressed this through construction of a short HRQoL measure, the Assessment of Quality of Life (AQoL)-8 from the original AQoL. Methods: Data from the AQoL validation database (N = 996) were reanalyzed using item response theory (IRT) to identify the least fitting items, which were removed. The standard AQoL scoring algorithm and weights were applied. Validity, reliability, and sensitivity tests were carried out using the 2004 South Australian Health Omnibus Survey (N = 3015), including direct comparisons with other short utility measures, the EQ5D and SF6D. Results: The IRT analysis showed that the AQoL was a weak scale (Loevinger H = 0.36) but reliable (Mokken rho = 0.84). Removal of the four weakest items led to an 8-item instrument with two items per subscale, the AQoL-8. The AQoL-8 Loevinger H = 0.38 and Mokken rho = 0.80 suggested similar psychometric properties to the AQoL. It correlated (intraclass correlation coefficient) 0.95 (or 90% of shared variance) with the AQoL. The AQoL-8 was as sensitive to six common health conditions as the AQoL, EQ5D, and SF6D. Conclusions: The utility scores fall on the same life-death scale as those of the AQoL. Where parsimony is imperative, researchers may consider use of the AQoL-8 to collect participant self-report HRQoL data that is suitable for use either as reported outcomes or for the calculation of quality-adjusted life-years for cost-utility analysis.

Authors: Szeinbach, SL; Baran, RW; Bratten, J; Jones, MP
Author Full Names: Szeinbach, Sheryl L.; Baran, Robert W.; Bratten, Jason; Jones, Michael P.
Article Title: Psychometric Development and Validation of the Chronic Constipation Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire (CTSAT-Q)
Author Keywords: chronic constipation; instrument development; irritable bowel syndrome; treatment satisfaction
Keywords Plus: QUALITY-OF-LIFE; IRRITABLE-BOWEL-SYNDROME; HEALTH-CARE; SYMPTOMS; BURDEN; PERSPECTIVE
Abstract: Objectives: To develop and validate the constipation treatment satisfaction questionnaire (CTSAT-Q) for use in patients with chronic constipation and irritable bowel syndrome with constipation (IBS-c). Methods: Questionnaire development included item representation from the reviewed literature, focus groups, and pretesting. Dimensions related to treatment satisfaction were identified with exploratory factor analysis, verified with confirmatory factor analysis (CFA), and tested with structural equation modeling. Results: A total of 31,988 email invitations were disseminated to obtain 311 qualified respondents with diagnoses for chronic constipation and IBS-c using ROME II criteria, which required that two of the following symptoms: fewer than 3 bowel movements per week, hard or lumpy stools, straining with defecation, and a sensation of incomplete evacuation, a sensation of anorectal obstruction, and the use of manual maneuvers to assist defecation be present 25% of the time during the last year. Approximately 84% of the sample was female. Item-to-total correlations were 0.66 for activities, ranged from 0.60 to 0.67 for expectations, from 0.59 to 0.69 for value, from 0.56 to 0.60 for effectiveness, and 0.68 to 0.79 for treatment satisfaction. All standardized parameter estimates from CFA were significant (P < 0.01). The chi-square was 46.98, df = 41, P = 0.241, comparative fit index = 0.996, Tucker-Lewis Index = 0.994, root mean square error of approximation = 0.022, indicating an excellent fit between the sample data and proposed model. Treatment satisfaction was a strong and significant predictor of effectiveness, activities, and value (P < 0.001). Conclusions: The CTSAT-Q was demonstrated to be reliable and valid, and appears to assess treatment satisfaction for patients with chronic constipation and patients with IBS-c.

Article Title: Can a single indicator measure both attainment and shortfall inequality?
Author Keywords: Inequality measurement; Bounded variables; Gini coefficient; Coefficient of Variation; Health inequality
Keywords Plus: DECOMPOSITION ANALYSIS; INCOME INEQUALITY; INFANT-MORTALITY; GINI INDEXES; ABSOLUTE; POVERTY
Abstract: When a distribution can be described either in terms of attainment or in terms of shortfall, the classical inequality measures appear to be one-sided. I show that it is possible to find indicators which simultaneously measure attainment and shortfall inequality. I derive one indicator belonging to the Gini family, and another belonging to Coefficient of Variation family. I also indicate how they are connected to other measures. (C) 2009 Elsevier B.V. Article Title: The private value of a patent: A cooperative approach
Author Keywords: Game theory; Patent licensing; Shapley value
Abstract: We consider a game in coalitional form played by the firms of a Cournot industry and an outside patent holder of a cost-reducing innovation. The worth of a coalition of players is the total Cournot profit of the active firms within this coalition. The number of firms that a coalition activates is determined by the Nash equilibrium of the game played by the coalition and its complement, where the strategy of each is the number of firms to be activated. Only firms in a coalition containing the patent holder are allowed to use the new technology. We prove that when the industry size increases indefinitely, the Shapley value of the patent holder approximates the payoff he obtains in a standard non-cooperative setup where he has the entire bargaining power. We also examine a partition game which considers for every coalition all structures of its complement, namely all partitions of the complement into sub-coalitions. The coalition and every sub-coalition of the complement simultaneously decide how many of their firms to be activated. We prove a similar equivalence result for an extension of the Shapley value from coalitional games to partition games. (C) 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Local structural quantile effects in a model with a nonseparable control variable
Author Keywords: Triangular models; Local instruments; Control variables; Quantile regression
Abstract: I consider a semiparametric version of the nonseparable triangular model of Chesher [Chesher, A., 2003. identification in nonseparable models. Econometrica 71, 1405-1441]. The proposed model is linear in coefficients, where the coefficients are unknown functions of unobserved latent variables. Using a control variable idea and quantile regression methods, I propose a simple two-step estimator for the coefficients evaluated at particular values of the latent variables. Under the condition that the instruments are locally relevant (i.e. they affect a particular conditional quantile of interest of the endogenous variable) I establish consistency and asymptotic normality. Simulation experiments confirm the theoretical results. (c) 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Obesity and Incremental Hospital Charges among Patients with and without Diabetes in the United States
Author Keywords: burden of illness; cost-of-illness; diabetes; hospital care
Keywords Plus: ACCELERATOR HYPOTHESIS; CHILDREN; PREVALENCE; CARE; OVERWEIGHT; DIAGNOSIS; TRENDS; ONSET; RISK; AGE
Abstract: Objective: The purpose of this study was to estimate the association between obesity and diabetes among inpatients in the United States as well as to investigate the incremental hospital charges attributable to obesity or morbid obesity. Methods: We analyzed the Nationwide Inpatient Sample 2005, a nationally representative probability sample that includes nearly 8 million inpatient records from US community hospitals. Results: During the past decade, the obesity among inpatients has steeply increased. In 2005, nearly 1.87 million hospitalizations were made by obese or morbidly obese patients. Both patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes were considerably more likely to be obese or morbidly obese compared with inpatients without diabetes (P < 0.01). The proportions of hospitalizations with obese or morbidly obese conditions were 4.5% among patients without diabetes, 6.5% among patients with type 1, and 12.2% among patients with type 2 diabetes. The hospital charges for obese and morbidly obese patients were 6.1% (P < 0.01) and 18.7% (P < 0.01) higher than that of the nonobese patients when diabetes status, sex, age, race, hospital admission type, and length of hospital stays were the same. Conclusions: Following a parallel rise in obesity among the general population, hospital admissions of obese and morbidly obese inpatients are continuously increasing. Morbidly obese patients consumed substantially more hospital resources regardless of the presence or type of diabetes. Under the current price-per-case reimbursement system, additional hospital resource use by this growing number of morbidly obese inpatients could be a burden to hospital financial systems.

Article Title: The impact of tax reforms designed to encourage healthier grain consumption
Author Keywords: Consumer economics; Food; Health; Taxation
Keywords Plus: CORONARY-HEART-DISEASE; DIETARY FIBER; SAMPLE SELECTION; GLYCEMIC INDEX; SNACK FOODS; RISK
Abstract: In this paper, we simulate the effects Of tax reforms aimed at encouraging healthier grain consumption. We use a rich data set on household grain consumption in 2003 from the market research institute GfK Sweden, combined with information oil the nutritional content of the consumption. We estimate behavioral parameters, which are used to simulate the impact on the average household of tax reforms entailing either a Subsidy oil commodities particularly rich in Fiber or a subsidy of the fiber density in grain products. Our results suggest that to direct the fiber intake towards nutritional recommendations, reforms with a substantial impact on consumer prices are required. Regardless of the type of subsidy implemented, the increase in the intake of Fiber is accompanied by unwanted increases in nutrients that are often overconsumed: far, salt and sugar Funding the subsidies by taxing these nutrients, or less healthy commodities, helps to counteract such developments. (C) 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sander, B; Nizam, A; Garrison, LP; Postma, MJ; Halloran, ME; Longini, IM
Author Full Names: Sander, Beate; Nizam, Azhar; Garrison, Louis P., Jr.; Postma, Maarten J.; Halloran, M. Elizabeth; Longini, Ira M., Jr.
Article Title: Economic Evaluation of Influenza Pandemic Mitigation Strategies in the United States Using a Stochastic Microsimulation Transmission Model
Author Keywords: computer simulation; cost-benefit analysis; economics; human disease outbreaks; influenza; pharmaceutical models; theoretical
Keywords Plus: COST-EFFECTIVENESS; OSELTAMIVIR; COMPLICATIONS; VACCINATION; PREVENTION; CHILDREN; HEALTH; IMPACT
Abstract: To project the potential economic impact of pandemic influenza mitigation strategies from a societal perspective in the United States. We use a stochastic agent-based model to simulate pandemic influenza in the community. We compare 17 strategies: targeted antiviral prophylaxis (TAP) alone and in combination with school closure as well as prevaccination. In the absence of intervention, we predict a 50% attack rate with an economic impact of $187 per capita as loss to society. Full TAP (FTAP) is the most effective single strategy, reducing number of cases by 54% at the lowest cost to society ($127 per capita). Prevaccination reduces number of cases by 48% and is the second least costly alternative ($140 per capita). Adding school closure to FTAP or prevaccination further improves health outcomes but increases total cost to society by approximately $2700 per capita. FTAP is an effective and cost-saving measure for mitigating pandemic influenza.

Authors: Sauerland, S; Weiner, S; Dolezalova, K; Angrisani, L; Noguera, CM; García-Caballero, M; Rupprecht, F; Immenroth, M
Author Full Names: Sauerland, Stefan; Weiner, Sylvia; Dolezalova, Karin; Angrisani, Luigi; Masdevall Noguera, Carlos; Garcia-Caballero, Manuel; Rupprecht, Frederic; Immenroth, Marc
Article Title: Mapping Utility Scores from a Disease-Specific Quality-of-Life Measure in Bariatric Surgery Patients
Author Keywords: bariatric surgery; economics; EQ-5D; health status indicators; quality of life
Keywords Plus: EVIDENCE-BASED GUIDELINES; BODY-MASS INDEX; HEALTH-STATUS; EQ-5D; OBESITY; ASSOCIATION; QUESTIONNAIRE; TRENDS; SF-6D; VAS
Abstract: To develop algorithms for a conversion of disease-specific quality-of-life into health state values for morbidly obese patients before or after bariatric surgery. A total of 893 patients were enrolled in a prospective cross-sectional multicenter study. In addition to demographic and clinical data, health-related quality-of-life (HRQoL) data were collected using the disease-specific Moorehead-Ardelt II questionnaire (MA-II) and two generic questionnaires, the EuroQoL-5D (EQ-5D) and the Short Form-6D (SF-6D). Multiple regression models were constructed to predict EQ-5D- and SF-6D-based utility values from MA-II scores and additional demographic variables. The mean body mass index was 39.4, and 591 patients (66%) had already undergone surgery. The average EQ-5D and SF-6D scores were 0.830 and 0.699. The MA-IIwas correlated to both utility measures (Spearman's r = 0.677 and 0.741). Goodness-of-fit was highest (R-2 = 0.55 in the validation sample) for the following item-based transformation algorithm: utility (MA-II-based) = 0.4293 + (0.0336 x MA1) + (0.0071 x MA2) + (0.0053 x MA3) + (0.0107 x MA4) + (0.0001 x MA5). This EQ-5D-based mapping algorithm outperformed a similar SF-6D-based algorithm in terms of mean absolute percentage error (P = 0.045). Because the mapping algorithm estimated utilities with only minor errors, it appears to be a valid method for calculating health state values in cost-utility analyses. The algorithm will help to define the role of bariatric surgery in morbid obesity.

Article Title: Problems in Managing Agricultural Land in Lithuania
Source Title: RURAL DEVELOPMENT 2009 PROCEEDINGS, VOL 4, BOOK 2, PROCEEDINGS
Book Series Title: Rural Development
Conference Title: 4th International Scientific Conference on Rural Development
Conference Location: Lithuanian Univ Agr Akad, Noreikiskes, LITHUANIA
Author Keywords: agricultural land; land management; rational land use
Abstract: The article presents analysis of situation with agricultural land in Lithuania and need for its further arrangement after the main land privatization activities are completed. Based on land management projects of the land reform, over 3 mil. ha of agricultural land parcels were formed and legitimized as private ownership. Parcels of such land are actively transferred to new owners, get subdivided, partitioned or otherwise reshaped. Due to the land management activities that involve changing of prime land use, agriculture loses similar to 2 thous. ha of land used for farming each year. Article gives suggestions on how the legal acts must facilitate rational forming of land tenures for farms, straiten decomposition and diminishing of arable land plots, and protect productive agricultural areas from their self-afforestation or from turning them into residential areas. Land management issues also involve regulation of rational land use. In 2005, about 650 thous. ha of agricultural land in Lithuania was not used for agricultural production, and part of land for meadows, pastures and perennial grass was used extensively. Article presents proposals for applying such juridical, economical and organizational measures which would encourage landowners of not cultivated land to transfer this land or lease it to agricultural entities and to comply with the recommendations set it area planning documents.

Article Title: Research on the Application of KMV Model in China
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: KMV Model; Default Distance; Default Point
Abstract: Attention is concentrated on the application of KMV model in China in the paper. Seven kinds of default points are set. Then the default distance will be calculated individually. The most suitable calculation model for default point in China's stock market will be established finally. Empirical analysis shows a very distinct gap between the default distance of an ST(special treatment) company and that of a non-ST(nonspecial treatment) company. It demonstrates that KMV model is effective in China. Furthermore, the regression equation with the intercept attained in the regression of total assets to current liabilities and long term liabilities is the most suitable for the situation of China in the setup of default point.

Author Full Names: Jonathan, Pan Juin Yang; Fung, Chun Che
Article Title: Malware's Impact on e-Business: they mean business!
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: Malware; e-Business; Critical Essential Infrastructure
Abstract: Malware is a dominant issue in the e-Business arena. It is affecting many of the key e-Business actors from the end users, to businesses offering online services to intermediaries and critical essential infrastructure needed to ensure continued e-Business activities. The impact of Malware is significant and wide ranging. The risk posed by Malware to e-Business actors has prompted variety of responses from the latter. However, the responses have mainly been a catch-up game by the targeted actors (or victims). Beyond the direct impact that Malware has on its targets, there are other forms of reactions that has been induced. Many of which has not been constructive or sufficient. More needs to be done quickly to mitigate the effects of Malware and to encourage the continual and healthy growth of e-Business.

Authors: Kripalani, S; Risser, J; Gatti, ME; Jacobson, TA
Author Full Names: Kripalani, Sunil; Risser, Jessica; Gatti, Margaret E.; Jacobson, Terry A.
Article Title: Development and Evaluation of the Adherence to Refills and Medications Scale (ARMS) among Low-Literacy Patients with Chronic Disease
Author Keywords: adherence; literacy; patient compliance; scale development
Keywords Plus: HEALTH LITERACY; SELF-EFFICACY; PREDICTORS; VALIDITY; OUTCOMES
Abstract: Patient literacy affects many aspects of medication use and may influence the measurement of adherence. The aim of the study is to design and evaluate a medication adherence scale suitable for use across levels of patient literacy. The Adherence to Refills and Medications scale (ARMS) was developed, pilot tested, and administered to 435 patients with coronary heart disease in an inner-city primary care clinic. Psychometric evaluation performed overall and by literacy level, included an assessment of internal consistency, test-retest reliability, and factor analysis. Criterion-related validity was evaluated by comparing scores with Morisky's self-reported measure of adherence, medication refill adherence, and blood pressure measurements. Lexile analysis was performed to assess the reading difficulty of the instrument. The final 12-item scale had high internal consistency overall (Cronbach's alpha = 0.814) and among patients with inadequate (alpha = 0.792) or marginal/adequate literacy skills (alpha = 0.828). Factor analysis yielded two subscales, which pertained to taking medications as prescribed and refilling medications on schedule. The ARMS correlated significantly with the Morisky adherence scale (Spearman's rho = -0.651, P < 0.01), and it correlated more strongly with measures of refill adherence than did the Morisky scale. Patients with low ARMS scores (which indicated better adherence) were significantly more likely to have controlled diastolic blood pressure (P < 0.05), and tended to have better systolic blood pressure control. Lexile analysis demonstrated that the instrument had a favorable reading difficulty level below the eight grade. The ARMS is a valid and reliable medication adherence scale when used in a chronic disease population, with good performance characteristics even among low-literacy patients.

Authors: Li, CQ; Ding, JL; Zhu, ZA
Book Editors: Duserick, FG
Author Full Names: Li, Chunqing; Ding, Jianlan; Zhu, Zhian
Article Title: Online Word-of-Mouth: Motives and Channels Based on the Personality Characteristics of Customers
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: Online WOM; motives; personality characteristics; channel
Abstract: Word-of-mouth (WOM) affects both business success and consumer purchase decisions. Along with the development of Internet, the definition of WOM has some new content, forming the online word-of-mouth, Electronic word-of-mouth or Word-of-Mouse. This paper studies the combined effects of the customers' personality characteristics, the channel of online WOM and the motives of online WOM. The results illustrate that the motives of online WOM are influence the choice of the channels of online WOM significantly, and the customers' personality characteristics are influence the motives and the choice of channels separately.

Authors: Lindeboorn, M; Llena-Nozal, A; van der Klaauw, B
Author Full Names: Lindeboorn, Maarten; Llena-Nozal, Ana; van der Klaauw, Bas
Article Title: Parental education and child health: Evidence from a schooling reform
Author Keywords: Returns to education; Intergenerational mobility; Health; Regression-discontinuity
Keywords Plus: INTERGENERATIONAL TRANSMISSION; IDENTIFICATION; REGRESSION; MORTALITY; GRADIENT; AVERAGE
Abstract: This paper investigates the impact of parental education oil child health outcomes. To identify the causal effect we explore exogenous variation in parental education induced by a schooling reform in 1947, which raised the minimum school leaving age in the UK. Findings based on data from the National Child Development Study suggest that increasing the school leaving age by 1 year had little effect on the health of their offspring. Schooling did however improve economic opportunities by reducing financial difficulties among households. (C) 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Abstract: The users' interests are always changed with time in Electronic Commerce. This paper constitute a neural network, with input multi-nerve information consisted of content characteristics of web page, users' apparent and implicit behavioral characteristics. Finally provide more accurate individual service through learning and adjusting the user' needing priority, so that it can automatic adapt to users' infesting.

Book Editors: Duserick, FG
Article Title: An Option Games Model Analysis on Investment Decisions of the Adoption of New Technology
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: Option games; real options; technology adoption
Abstract: In dynamic uncertain environments, the investment timing of the firm about adopting the existing new technology is influenced by the rival's actions and technological progress. This paper exploits option games approach to examine the impact of operating costs and technological innovations on firms' strategic irreversible investment decisions. In the model, the irreversible investment in adoption of the existing new technology is in strategic competitive circumstances and facing the arrival of a further new technology after the competition setting is established, which the further new technology can reduce operating costs. The study shows that the rapid technological innovation encourages the follower's investment and discourages the leader's investment, when the operating cost reduction is greater enough and the investment cost is lower enough of the further new technology. However, the case is the opposite when the operating cost reduction isn't greater enough and the investment cost isn't lower enough of the further new technology. The higher operating cost and the larger investment cost of the existing new technology, the lower cost reduction and the larger investment cost of the further new technology, the greater volatility of the market demand, and the greater first-mover advantage delay the follower's investment, instead, hasten the leader's investment. Comparing with the optimal timing without the adoption of the further new technology, the firm delays its investment when no firm has invested; however, once one firm has invested first, the firm will hasten to invest, when the operating cost reduction is greater enough and the investment cost is lower enough of the further new technology.

Article Title: MODEL FOR MEASURING AND ANALYSING COSTS IN BUSINESS INFORMATICS
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: business informatics; economic efficiency; accounting; cost; business intelligence; measuring; model
Abstract: This paper is devoted to problems of management of cost efficiency of business informatics with Business Intelligence (BI) assistance. It defines basic critical points that must be taken into account during creating models for management of cost efficiency of business informatics. It proposes new model for management of cost efficiency, this model include also definitions of dimensions and indicators for measuring of this cost efficiency. The model takes into account requirements that pose claim on management of cost efficiency necessitated by accounting and requirements from consultancy with managers of companies. It also takes into account requirement of methodologies for management business informatics and methods and processes for evaluating and measuring business informatics. This methodologies, methods and processes are transformed into procedures that are appropriate for measuring and evaluating business informatics. This model is intended for monitoring of actual situation, evolution cost efficiency of business informatics and it can be used for making decisions about convenience of outsourcing of business informatics. There are presented some examples from presentation level of mentioned model for measuring of cost efficiency of business informatics. This presentation level is in the form of tables and also in the form of dashboards.

Article Title: The Evaluation of the Humidity of Vegetation Period
Source Title: RURAL DEVELOPMENT 2009 PROCEEDINGS, VOL 4, BOOK 2, PROCEEDINGS
Book Series Title: Rural Development
Conference Title: 4th International Scientific Conference on Rural Development
Conference Location: Lithuanian Univ Agr Akad, Noreikiskes, LITHUANIA
Abstract: The fertility of agricultural vegetation basically depends on the terms and hydrologic conditions of vegetation period. These conditions are determined by warmth and precipitation and its distribution. This article analyzes the methods of the evaluation of these conditions in the period of active vegetation (in May-September). The calculations received applying these methods are presented and the differences between the last 60-80 vegetation periods are shown. In order to define the differences between the indirect methods of humidity evaluation, the methods used in Lithuania G.Selyaninov's hydrothermal coefficient (HTC) and A. Dirse's coefficient of complex humidity (K), which evaluates the resources of the soil moisture are analyzed and compared. It is noticed that the humidity, evaluated applying HTC and K, is different. The periods in January, evaluated applying HTC, make 18% and, evaluated applying the complex coefficient K, make 27% of the total investigated period, or accordingly - 28% and 15% characterizing the period of one month. According to the results of the analysis, it is stated that the complex coefficient K is more precise in evaluating the period of humidity in the climatic Lithuanian conditions. In addition, it is suggested to specify the methodology of the evaluation of the humidity of vegetation periods, relating the applied K and HTC coefficients with the actual soil moisture content.

Article Title: Ecohydraulic Criteria for Small HPP Impact on Biotic Environment
Source Title: RURAL DEVELOPMENT 2009 PROCEEDINGS, VOL 4, BOOK 2, PROCEEDINGS
Book Series Title: Rural Development
Conference Title: 4th International Scientific Conference on Rural Development
Conference Location: Lithuanian Univ Agr Akad, Noreikiskes, LITHUANIA
Abstract: The impact of a hydropower plant (HPP) on the environment, first at all in downstream reaches is analyzed in the paper. The impact on habitat quality changes can be estimated by the ecohydraulic parameters such as velocity, water depth, Froude Number (Fr), turbulence and vorticity regimes fluctuation Analysis of literature and experiment results from Virvyte and Susve HPP turbines operation regimes suggests that dams and reservoirs may impart change in the environment though facility operations over a sustained period. In pounded reaches nearby above HPP dams of Virvyte River low Fr number habitats (0.04 > Fr > 0.0007) were created and negative dam impact was observed. A large disturbance experiment when a positive wave front resulting from an increase of initial sanitary flow rate Q(s)=0.4m(3)/s till total flow rate Q(tot)=10.4 m(3)/s moving downstream after the switch on turbines was made The maximal water level increase speed Delta h/Delta t=0.18 m/min=10.8 m/h was fixed on the second minute from the beginning As a positive surge can travel over very long distance without losing much energy because it is self - perpetuating damaging of downstream biota, it is evident that in practice rapid operation of HPP turbines switch must be avoided.

Book Editors: Duserick, FG
Article Title: An Empirical Analysis on the Relationship between Chinese Economic Growth and Inflation during 1953-2007
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: economic growth; inflation; causality; correlation
Abstract: This paper focuses on doing an empirical analysis on the relationship between the Chinese economic growth and inflation by using the econometric models of ARDL, VAR and VECM during the three different periods of 1953-1978, 1979-2007 and 1953-2007. The empirical analysis has achieved four results. Firstly, it has approved that the structure relation between the Chinese economic growth and inflation has been changed since 1979. Secondly, the correlation between the Chinese economic growth and inflation was substantial negative during 1953-1978; however, it became substantial positive during 1979-2007. Thirdly, there was not any Granger causality relation between the Chinese economic growth and inflation during 1953-1978, but there was a two-way Granger causality between them during 1979-2007 in the short run and long run. Finaly, the unequilibrium between the Chinese economic growth and inflation could be adjusted during 1979-2007, but it was inversely during 1953-1978.

Article Title: The Method of Optimizing Financial Distress Prediction Indicators of SINOPEC Corp. and its Subsidiaries
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: financial distress prediction; indicators; principal component analysis; quantitative and qualitative method
Abstract: The prediction of financial distress has received considerable attention in accounting and corporate financial literatures for decades. Various quantitative prediction methods based on financial ratios derived from financial statements have been proposed. However, the important role of managers' experiential knowledge and non-financial information has been ignored. A method integrating quantitative analysis and qualitative analysis is put forward to realize effective selection of financial distress prediction indicators in the process of modeling financial distress prediction. The purpose of this paper is to provide Sinopec Corp. and its subsidiaries a good method to forecast their financial status efficiently, conveniently and accurately. The Case study of Sinopec YIZHENG Chemical fibre Company is carried out at section 3, which indicates that the proposed method is more suitable for financial distress prediction than single quantitative analysis.

Article Title: Implementation Method of Supply Chain Management based on PLM for Automobile Industry
Source Title: EIGHTH WUHAN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON E-BUSINESS, VOLS I-III
Conference Title: 8th Wuhan International Conference on E-Business
Conference Sponsor: China Univ Geosci,CICEB,Coll Econ & Management,Coll Business,Alfred Univ
Author Keywords: Product Lifecycle Management (PLM); Supply Chain Management (SCM); Implementation Method
Abstract: Through the combination of product lifecycle management (PLM) and supply chain management (SCM), the implementation method of SCM based on PLM is put forward and the correspondent model of the three-dimensional structure model (i.e. the supply chain implementation stage dimension, PLM technology dimension and SCM objectives dimension) is given which shows the effect of PLM technology in realizing the objectives of SCM at each stage of the supply chain. Meanwhile, the multi-objective programming method is used to construct SCM multi-objective model based on PLM and an example is given. According to the comparison and analysis of the values of decision variables resulted from the model and the objective values, the effect of the implementation method of SCM based on PLM and the weak aspects of SCM are pointed out.

Abstract: Changsha, Zhuzhou and Xiangtan(CZT)-three cities lie in the East central of Hunan Province are nominated as comprehensive reform pilot area of two-oriented society construction. The paper analyzes basic development situations of low-carbon society in this pilot area, proposing the routes and objectives of low-carbon social development. Further, from aspects of energy conservation, energy structure, low-carbon industry, low-carbon buildings, low-carbon traffic system, low-carbon consumption, low-carbon management, it investigates the development path in CZT.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: urban unemployment; shadow price of environment; waste management
Abstract: Developing countries often face the dilemma of balancing unemployment with environmental protection. Waste management in particular is a major concern in such countries. We consider optimal waste management policy in the presence of urban unemployment following Harris and Todaro (1970). Our results suggest that the optimal policy should be designed to reflect regional characteristics and the technological aspects of disposal.

Article Title: Study for the enterprise value on the mergers and acquisitions
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: mergers and acquisitions; market model; long-run performance; tobin's Q value
Abstract: The research on the performance of mergers and acquisitions has focused on stock returns around the merger announcement. Mergers and acquisitions are one of the actively researched topics in finance. This paper examines the financial performance of the firm after mergers and acquisitions, using market model. Our findings show that following mergers and acquisitions, the long run performance of M&A is negative. This decline seems reflected in the failure prediction. At the same time we discover that the value of the enterprise increase significantly after enterprise M&A.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: climate change; microfinance; poverty
Abstract: Climate change leads to a higher incidence and severity of natural disasters in global, and it inevitably has an adverse affect on Microfinance institutions which devote themselves to improve the situation of the poor. On the basis of analyzing the impact mechanism of climate change on Microfinance, this paper summarizes some efforts and innovation of microfinance institutions around the world in addressing climate change and proposes the focus developing direction of our county's Microfinance institutions in addressing climate change according to our country's present development situation.

Article Title: Trade Competitiveness of Chinese Agro-products under Green Trade Barriers: Challenges and Solutions
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: green trade barriers; agro-products; trade competitiveness; international market
Abstract: Given the special status and the multifunction of agriculture in the national economy, the agro-product trade is highly protected in the world. However, after the entry to the WTO, especially since 2004, China has experienced a long term of trade deficit in agro-product, an ongoing decreasing of export competitiveness in international market, which is widely believed to mainly result from the hindrance of green trade barriers (GTBs). Based on the studies of the characteristics of international agricultural market, this paper conducts detailed analysis of the challenges in Chinese agricultural trade and explored the causes in term with three perspectives: demand, supply and constructional environment. Following that some practical suggestions are discussed.

Article Title: The Test of Unbiased Forecast in Soybean Futures Market Based on Panel Data
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: unbiased forecast; Soybean futures; panel data; PCSE
Abstract: In this paper, the panel-data model of the unbiased futures price forecasting was constructed by using the data of the Soybean futures price and spot price. After testing the heteroscedasticity, serial correlation and contemporaneous correlation in the model, we estimated the model by the OLS estimator with panel corrected standard errors (PCSE). The empirical result showed that the Soybean futures price was the unbiased forecast of the spot price within 4 month in which the futures contract is away from its maturity, the soybean futures market according with the hypothesis of the Simple efficiency.

Based on the comparative analysis of PFI and BOT and PFI feasibility analysis, the paper shows that in the absence of sufficient state finance, PFI can be used as one of the modes that financing highway construction.

Article Title: Research and Practice of the Way How Highly Qualified Engineers are Being Formed - Case study of a pilot scheme for a training of innovative senior engineers at Central South University
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: technical staff; cooperation between universities and enterprises; personnel draining; modes; practice
Abstract: The development of low carbon economy depends on a large number of highly qualified engineers working in their respective sectors who not only should be in possession of low carbon expertise necessary for solving practical engineering problems but also should be innovative and internationally competitive. This article is intended to suggest an optimization of the ways of forming highly qualified technical staff based on the experience of the training course of innovative senior engineers of Central South University and through an analysis of the current training of highly qualified engineers in China. Theoretical research has been conducted starting from practical work to explore the way of forming high qualification engineers and could be of value of reference in helping to optimize such a training.

Article Title: The Growth Path Choice of Chinese Life Insurance Companies in Transition Period
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: transition period; life insurance companies; growth mode; choice of path
Abstract: In post-financial crisis era, the internal and external development environment of the Chinese insurance industry has undergone drastic changes. The extensive development mode is gradually replaced by the intensive growth mode. The domestic life insurance companies have been trying to achieve its sustainable growth in the transition period and to enhance their core competitiveness by active participating in policy-related business, speeding up structural adjustment, highlighting the main business management, optimizing resource allocation, and vigorously promoting technological innovation, etc.

Abstract: As an urban tourism infrastructure and a newly emerging operating mode, tourist service center (TSC, also known as tourist transport & service center in many Chinese cities) is playing a constructive role in tourism industry. TSCs have been established since 2008 in 57 cities in the Chinese mainland such as Shanghai, Beijing and Shenzhen, and there is a growing tendency for the centers to be set up throughout China. The project of Hunan Tourist Service Center (HTSC) conforms to this trend. Based on investigation data, the authors analyzed the characteristics of tourist demands among the potential tourists, tourism enterprises and tourism-related institutions, demonstrating that Hunan Tourist Service Center must be based on actual situation in Hunan and place emphasis on its own features in order to make the center one of the unique and most energetic provincial tourist service centers in China.

Abstract: This article firstly describes the characteristics of main export market of live pigs in Hunan, and then conducts comparative analysis on the international competitiveness of live pigs in Hunan and main foreign competitors from production costs, import and export prices, and revealed comparative advantages. Abstract: This article, used domestic listed companies as study samples, had made empirical analysis on organizational scale and wage rate correlation. The results showed that the organizational scale of listed companies is positively correlated with wage rate, namely, the larger the organization, the higher wage rate of employees. At the same time, this article had discussed how organizational scale of listed companies improves wage rates and had found that labor productivity, profit sharing, and corporate life had some explanatory power on the effect of organizational scale on improving wage rate.

Article Title: Research on the Strategy Path Choice of Carbon Finance in China
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: Low Carbon Economy; Carbon Finance; Financial Innovations
Abstract: With the development of carbon market, carbon finance is come into being. And its development has important strategic significance to the development of low-carbon economy, sustainable economic development, and enhancement of international competitiveness. In recent years, international carbon finance market developed rapidly, while there are a series of constrained factors in the development of Chinese carbon finance such as lack of pricing power and a unified national trading platform, low proportion of financing directly, incomplete development of intermediary institutions, insufficient supply of carbon financial instruments, lack of risk diversification mechanism. We should take some countermeasures to promote the sustained and healthy development of Chinese carbon finance, such as intensifying policy support, fostering a unified national trading platform, Establishing a multi-level carbon finance market system, constructing a risk spreading mechanism, training carbon finance talents, and establishing carbon financial intermediaries.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: The Privacy Jungle: On the Market for Data Protection in Social Networks
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: We have conducted the first thorough analysis of the market for privacy practices and policies in online social networks. From an evaluation of 45 social networking sites using 260 criteria we find that many popular assumptions regarding privacy and social networking need to be revisited when considering the entire ecosystem instead of only a handful of well-known sites. Contrary to the common perception of an oligopolistic market, we find evidence of vigorous competition for new users. Despite observing many poor security practices, there is evidence that social network providers are making efforts to implement privacy enhancing technologies with substantial diversity in the amount of privacy control offered. However, privacy is rarely used as a selling point, even then only as auxiliary, non-decisive feature. Sites also failed to promote their existing privacy controls within the site. We similarly found great diversity in the length and content of formal privacy policies, but found an opposite promotional trend: though almost all policies are not accessible to ordinary users due to obfuscating legal jargon, they conspicuously vaunt the sites' privacy practices. We conclude that the market for privacy in social networks is dysfunctional in that there is significant variation in sites' privacy controls, data collection requirements, and legal privacy policies, but this is not effectively conveyed to users. Our empirical findings motivate us to introduce the novel model of a privacy communication game, where the economically rational choice for a site operator is to make privacy control available to evade criticism from privacy fundamentalists, while hiding the privacy control interface and privacy policy to maximize sign-up numbers and encourage data sharing from the pragmatic majority of users.

Authors: Grossklags, J; Johnson, B; Christin, N
Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Author Full Names: Grossklags, Jens; Johnson, Benjamin; Christin, Nicolas
Article Title: The Price of Uncertainty in Security Games
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: In the realm of information security, lack of information about other users' incentives in a network can lead to inefficient security choices and reductions in individuals' payoffs. We propose, contrast and compare three metrics for measuring the price of uncertainty due to the departure from the payoff-optimal security outcomes under complete information. Per the analogy with other efficiency metrics, such as the price of anarchy, we define the price of uncertainty as the maximum discrepancy in expected payoff in a complete information environment versus the payoff in an incomplete information environment. We consider difference, payoff-ratio, and cost-ratio metrics as canonical nontrivial measurements of the price of uncertainty. We conduct an algebraic, numerical, and graphical analysis of these metrics applied to different well-studied security scenarios proposed in prior work (i.e., best shot, weakest-link, and total effort). In these scenarios, we study how a fully rational expert agent could utilize the metrics to decide whether to gather information about the economic incentives of multiple nearsighted and naive agents. We find substantial differences between the various metrics and evaluate the appropriateness for security choices in networked systems.

Article Title: Study on the Innovative System Governance Mechanism of High-tech Enterprises on the Basis of Ecology
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network

Abstract: Innovation of high-tech enterprises can be taken as an eco-evolutionary system, a coexistent innovation system linked by technical standards. Effective operation of innovative ecosystem depends on whether the governance mechanism can ensure partners to have enough motives not to take advantage of their asymmetric information and incomplete contract to seek personal gains. To prevent such opportunistic behaviors as hold-up behavior, pick-up behavior, withdrawal menace, concealment and false release of information, etc. caused by asymmetric information of the innovative ecosystem, the innovative ecosystem governance mechanism of high-tech enterprises is studied and demonstrated respectively in terms of the decision-making mechanism, negotiation and coordination mechanism, platform pricing mechanism, and constraint mechanism, etc.

Authors: Cezar, A; Cavusoglu, H; Raghunathan, S
Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Author Full Names: Cezar, Asunur; Cavusoglu, Huseyin; Raghunathan, Srinivasan
Article Title: Competition, Speculative Risks, and IT Security Outsourcing
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: Information security management is becoming a more critical and, simultaneously, a challenging function for many firms. Even though many security managers are skeptical about outsourcing of IT security, others have cited reasons that are used for outsourcing of traditional IT functions for why security outsourcing is likely to increase. Our research offers a novel explanation, based on competitive externalities associated with IT security, for firms' decisions to outsource IT security. We show that if competitive externalities are ignored, then a firm will outsource security if and only if the MSSP offers a quality (or a cost) advantage over in-house operations, which is consistent with the traditional explanation for security outsourcing. However, a higher quality is neither a prerequisite nor a guarantee for a firm to outsource security. The competitive risk environment and the nature of the security function outsourced, in addition to quality, determine firms' outsourcing decisions. If the reward from the competitor's breach is higher than the loss from own breach, then even if the likelihood of a breach is higher under the MSSP the expected benefit from the competitive demand externality may offset the loss from the higher likelihood of breaches, resulting in one or both firms outsourcing security. The incentive to outsource security monitoring is higher than that of infrastructure management because the MSSP can reduce the likelihood of breach on both firms and thus enhance the demand externality effect. The incentive to outsource security monitoring (infrastructure management) is higher (lower) if either the likelihood of breach on both firms is lower (higher) when security is outsourced or the benefit (relative to loss) from the externality is higher (lower). Article Title: The Research on Changing Development Paths: from a High-carbon to Low-carbon Economy in China
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: climate change mitigation; development; high-carbon economy; low-carbon economy; sustainable development
Abstract: The contradiction between the environment and the development of economy is going more and more outstanding in the 21 century. Climate change mitigation also poses significant challenges for China and its energy development, historically highly energy-intensive. Examining this challenge, this paper considers how to choose effective path to achieve the transformation of the economy growth pattern from the energy-intensive and high-carbon to low-carbon and no-carbon under the current limits of economy, population, resource, environment, and technical conditions, etc. In the short term, energy efficiency provides large potential for mitigation. Changing energy structure, dependent to 70% on coal, is at least a medium-term challenge. The most transformative change is to an alteration industry structure, likely to take long to achieve. In the future, the carbon dioxide emissions will have to stop growing, stabilize and decline 40%-50% before mid-century in China. The challenge of climate change is a long-term challenge, requiring immediate action. This article is focus on seeking to shift development paths.

Article Title: The Adverse Selection of Green Market and Signaling Strategies in China
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: green market; information asymmetry; adverse selection; signaling
Abstract: As people's consumption level is improving, the new consumption ideas such as nature, health, nutrition and environmental protection have been spread widely among Chinese consumers, and people have paid unprecedented attention to environmental-friendly products. However, because of its high quality, green products fail to price at a favorable premiumn, which hinder the development of green product industry. Based on information economics theories, this thesis argued that this phenomenon was caused by information asymmetry in green product market, and some signaling strategies should be deployed by firms and government.

Article Title: The research of low-rent housing institution in Hunan province based on the theory of four-quadrant model
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: four-quadrant model; low-rent housing; real estate
Abstract: The issue of low-rent housing is a matter of political democracy in our country, reflecting the civil rights and ensuring the livelihood. A complete management system needs to be set up for our low-rent houses. Taking Changsha city as the example, the paper analyzes the necessity for improving low-rent housing institution in the background of constructing two-oriented society. With the help of four-quadrant model of housing demand, the paper analyzes the issue of Hunan province's low-rent housing and then proposes the relevant policy suggestions.

Article Title: The Development Prospects and Countermeasure of Forest Tourism in Low-carbon Economy Era
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low-carbon economy; forest tourism; prospects; countermeasure
Abstract: Low-carbon economy is the hotspot and trend in world economic development. Low-carbon tourism demands tourists to minimize emitting CO(2) while travelling. It is a type of green tourism based on low power consumption, low level of pollution and low emission. The current research on low-carbon tourism and low-carbon forest tourism mainly focus on the concepts and practial use, and it needs further research on the aspect of theoretical study. China is very rich in forest resources which have great Carbon sequestration functions. Forest is the best carrier to develop low-carbon tourism. This paper proposes to protect the low-carbon forest tourism from four aspects. First, as for policy enforcement-to develop the incentive policies and improve the management system; Second, as for technical support -to strengthen technical research and development and emphasize on promoting and application; Third, as for capital protection -to broaden the funding sources and increase loaning intensity; Fourth, as for publicity -to strengthen publicity and to give the proper guidance.

Article Title: Financial Support of Institutional Innovation for the Rural Land Transfer
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: rural land; the system of transfer; financial innovation
Abstract: Rural land transfer is the product of agricultural and rural development to a certain stage, is an effective improvement of the rural land system based on the existing household contract responsibility system, is a breakthrough and key of a new round of rural reform. This paper puts forward the channels of financial innovation for the system of rural land transfer, through analyzing its basis and bottle-neck, which will be of great practical and far-reaching historical significance to develop modern agriculture, turn the industrialization of agriculture into reality, operate on a large-scale, and achieve sustainable economic development in rural areas.

Article Title: An Empirical Study on Customer Satisfaction Determinants in Chinese Service Recovery Context
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: service failure; service recovery; satisfaction; service fairness; expectancy disconfirmation
Abstract: This study aims to explore the empirical effects of recovery efforts on satisfaction in China's banking industry in term of four variables: expectation, perceived recovery quality, causality attribution, and service fairness. Based on Goodwin's justice framework, Boshoff's RECOVSAT scale and PZB's SERVQUAL scale, we design the questionnaire and conduct the survey. Our study shows, most respondents attributed the service failure to banks, and thought they were controllable, yet occurred frequently, which leads to a low level of first time satisfaction. And a big gap between recovery expectation and perceived recovery efforts, leads to poor post recovery satisfaction. In practice, this study highlights the importance of good understanding of customer expectation and effective communication with customers in banking industry.

The taxation policies play an important role on balancing and promoting the logistical industry, which are paid most attention by the logistical enterprises. On the basis of analyzing the logistical industry tax system and indicators of tax rates, this paper puts forward several related suggestions to improve the logistical industry.

Article Title: International Carbon Emissions Trading System and China's Development Strategy of Carbon Finance
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: climate warming; carbon finance; the Kyoto mechanisms; non-Kyoto mechanisms; carbon emission trading mechanism; China
Abstract: Under the background of global warming and based on the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Kyoto Protocol, carbon finance arises out of the market mechanism of greenhouse gas emissions reduction. The existing international carbon emission trading system is divided into the Kyoto mechanisms and non-Kyoto mechanisms. The Kyoto Protocol has created four mechanisms, respectively IET mechanism, JI mechanism, CDM mechanism and RMU mechanism. Most of non-Kyoto mechanisms adopt the policy of cap and trade. Several far-reaching non-Kyoto mechanisms is the EU emissions trading scheme, the U.S. regional carbon emission trading scheme and Australia's New South Wales greenhouse gas abatement scheme. For China's development strategy of carbon finance, there are significant errors of over-reliance on the Kyoto mechanisms. China should speed up the pilot scheme of regional carbon emissions trading system and create its own carbon credit products.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: Nobody Sells Gold for the Price of Silver: Dishonesty, Uncertainty and the Underground Economy
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: The underground economy has attracted a lot of attention recently as a key component of cybercrime. In particular the IRC markets for stolen identities, phishing kits, botnets, and cybercrime related services have been extensively studied. It is suggested that sophisticated underground markets show great specialization and maturity. There are complex divisions of labor and service offerings for every need. Stolen credentials are traded in bulk for pennies on the dollar. It is suggested that large sums move on these markets. We argue that this makes very little sense. Using basic arguments from economics we show that the IRC markets studied represent classic examples of lemon markets. The ever-present rippers who cheat other participants ensure that the market cannot operate effectively. Their presence represents a tax on every transaction conducted in the market. Those who form gangs and alliances avoid this tax, enjoy a lower cost basis and higher profit. This suggests a two tier underground economy where organization is the route to profit. The IRC markets appear to be the lower tier, and are occupied by those without skills or alliances, newcomers, and those who seek to cheat them. The goods offered for sale there are those that are easy to acquire, but hard to monetize. We find that estimates of the size of the IRC markets are greatly exaggerated. Finally, we find that defenders recruit their own opponents by publicizing exaggerated estimates of the rewards of cybercrime. Those so recruited inhabit the lower tier; they produce very little profit, but contribute greatly to the externalities of cybercrime.

Article Title: On the Construction of Low-carbon Consumption Pattern in China
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: construction; low carbon; consumption; patterns
Abstract: Suffering greatly from the effects of global warming in the 21st century, our human beings gradually realize that low carbon economy is of great significance to the global development. While focusing much on production sphere, the public hasn't paid enough attention to consumption which has imposed significant impact on development of low carbon economy as well. Especially in recent years, with the improvement of people's living standards, energy consumption of residents which has been now far beyond that of industrial sectors, is increasingly becoming a significant growth point in carbon emissions. By review of the historical succession for human consumption patterns which include primitive consumption pattern, linear consumption pattern, cyclic consumption pattern, sustainable consumption pattern and low carbon consumption pattern, this paper takes an in-depth look into the present consumption status in China from such aspects as consumption of energy, carbon emissions in China, the main characteristics of present consumption patterns, and tries to put forward some countermeasure and advices for the construction of low-carbon consumption pattern.

Article Title: Empirical Research On China's Foreign Trade And Economic Growth: 1979-2008
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: foreign trade; economic growth; Co-integration; Error Correction Model; Granger Causality Test
Abstract: Based on the relevant data from 1979 to 2008 and by Co-integration and Granger Causality Test, this paper expounds the empirical relations between foreign trade and economic growth in China. Co-integration test discoverys that the long-term relation between them has positive correlation, ECM indicates that the short-term relation between them has negative correlation, but the latter influence is much smaller than the former; Although the short-term disequilibrium is inevitable, it can be in convergence to the long-term equilibrium and The foreign trade change causes the economic growth, but is not in the reverse direction As a result, the paper puts forward the corresponding policy proposals.

Article Title: Game Analysis on Polluting Firms and Government Governance in Energy Conservation and Emission Reduction
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: energy conservation and emission reduction; government governance; polluting firms; game theory
Abstract: The goals of the energy conservation and emission reduction and promoting low carbon economics' development have become all nations' consensus. The energy conservation and emission reduction have strong externality, and will increase the production cost of firms. So we must rely on government increases investment on the energy conservation and emission reduction to guide the firms to adopt them. Based on game theory this paper makes analysis on the behaviours between polluting firms and government in course of the energy conservation and emission reduction, and studies the factors which effect the probability and success of adopting measures of the energy saving and emission reduction in polluting firms. The results find that government increases investment on the firms, especially on the technology and equipment can improve the probability and success of adopting measures of the energy saving and emission reduction in polluting firms, and the cost of the firms adopting measurements of the energy saving and emission reduction is the key success factor which blocks the probability of success of adopting them, but the rewards and punishment of government have indirect effect on the promotion of the energy conservation and emission reduction.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: tax planning risk; risk evaluation; second-order Fuzzy Synthesis Evaluation
Abstract: After identifying business tax planning risks by AHP Method, the paper constructs a business tax planning risk tree model and establishes a risk set, and applies Delphi Method and Fuzzy Synthesis Evaluation Method to assess business planning risk. According to evaluating the risk after quantifying the risk values, we can decide whether or not to receive the business tax planning scheme. In order to enhance the credit degree of the business tax planning risk evaluation results, the paper applies Delphi Method with credit degree to determine the weight of risk and second-order Fuzzy Synthesis Evaluation method to evaluate in the empirical analysis.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: International Low Carbon Society and International Eco-Compensation: by Viewpoint of Circulation Society
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: Wide sense economy reproduction process; vicious circle society; Zero Desire; Zero Industry; harmony type circulation society; International Eco-Compensation Mechanism; common but differentiated responsibilities; International low carbon society
Abstract: Environmental problems are becoming intensified. For example, the drying up of fossil fuel resources (crude oil, liquid gas, and dry gas) and the global warming are the typical problems. It is related to circulation of the carbon. For them, the present system of economy society is changing inevitably. We know now that the environmental consciousness of economic field is changing and environmental industries are expanding. For finding a way of the new economy society concerning with them, this report considers the harmony type circulation society and the next issues. And In this paper, recognized that the low-carbon society following. The first is a meaning of the low carbon society to understand from a circulation social viewpoint. The important point is relevance of the harmony type circulation society and the low carbon society. The second is a necessary condition of the low carbon society judging from the change of human desire and the lifestyle. The important point is the expansion of zero desire and Eco-consumption. The third is a necessary condition of the low carbon society judging from the change of Industrial activity and industrial structure. The important point is expansion of zero industry and Eco-management. The fourth is a necessary condition of the international low carbon society judging from an international action about the global environment problem. The important point is the environmental technology transfer and an International Eco-Compensation Mechanism. Therefore the development of international policy means of multi dimensions (a market mechanism, a non-market mechanism, and also a deliberation market mechanism) must be pushed forward. This is a problem to depend on effectiveness. The ICE emphasizes the above-mentioned common but differentiated responsibilities and the durability, equitableness, effectiveness.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: DEA; agricultural productivity; evaluation
Abstract: The application of Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) in economic system is virtually probing resource allocation problems. The study employs DEA theory to evaluate agricultural production efficiency of 31 provinces and cities in China in 2008. Via empirical study on input-output data of agricultural production, this paper concludes that Beijing and five other provinces have reached the optimal scale of agricultural production and their investment structure is effective as well; Due to investment in agricultural production structure is not reasonable, Shandong and 26 other provinces and cities is still relatively low in agricultural productivity. Overall, modernization degree of agricultural production in China is not very high, scale efficiency and technical efficiency need to be improved, to further increase investment in agricultural technology and modernization.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low carbon tourism; low carbon experience; rural tourism; 5-wheel-driving
Abstract: Nowadays rural tourism has become one of the modern living styles in Chinese urban dwellers because of the participation, experiential, cultural and the unique active object. The accommodation, catering, entertainment, transportation, sightseeing and shopping of rural tourism can bring carbon emissions. The 5-wheel-driving low carbon experiential rural tourism model is constructed from such 5 aspects as developing the low carbon rural landscape, constructing the low carbon rural facilities, implementing the low carbon consumption patterns of rural tourism, creating an authentic low carbon rural tourism environment and the low carbon-based life of local residents. As for how to achieve the low carbon experiential rural tourism is discussed. The assessment system of low carbon experiential rural tourism is constructed which can lead the experiential rural tourism towards the low carbon economy era.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY

Author Keywords: blue barriers; export trade; economic effect
Abstract: As being an extremely hidden, rational, pertinent and flexible forms of non-tariff barriers, blue barriers have become the new tools to restrict China's labor-intensive products export in the current. By analyzing and studying the economic effect of the blue barrier, this paper makes a conclusion that blue barrier set by the developed countries will make negative effect to China's export trade in a short time while it will have positive effect in a long time. Meanwhile, the conclusion shows that blue barrier will make dual effects on a country's export trade.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Author Full Names: Wang, Qing; Liu, Kewang; Shi, Xiuhua
Article Title: Study on the Dominant Mangrove Population in Shenzhen
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: niche breadth; niche overlap; competition index
Abstract: Aegiceras corniculatum, Kandelia candel and Avicennia marina are dominant species in arbor layer of mangrove performing mostly ecological function. Analyzing the intraspecific and interspecific relationship between Aegiceras corniculatum, Kandelia candel and Avicennia marina by commonly used niche calculation formula and Hegyi single-tree competition index mode, it is found that Aegiceras corniculatum and Kandelia candel have extreme similar niche breadth and high value of niche overlap index. The Hegyi single-tree competition index also shows there is tense competition between Aegiceras corniculatum and Kandelia candel to survive. And it can be calculated that Aegiceras corniculatum and Kandelia candel will live together for a long time.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: Internet Multi-Homing Problems: Explanations from Economics
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: Companies seeking to ensure that their Internet connection is resilient often purchase services from multiple providers. This leads them inexorably towards having their IP address range visible in the global routing table, increasing the resource usage of every Internet router. Since this is essentially 'free', yet impacts the cost and stability of every router in the world, this is a classic 'tragedy of the commons'. There is little prospect of change in the IPv4 world, but there is a chance to fix the problem as IPv6 is rolled out. Unfortunately, SHIM6, the engineering solution chosen to solve this issue in IPv6, will only be effective if universally adopted, and there are no short-term incentives to prefer SHIM6 over a duplication of the IPv4 arrangements. Incentives could be artificially introduced by requiring payment for adding multi-homed address space to the global routing table-a naive estimate of the actual cost being $77 000 per routing prefix. However, it would be almost impossible to ensure the substantial revenues involved are correctly redistributed to those bearing the costs.

Article Title: Study on regional differences in carbon emissions based on STIRPAT model
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: STIRPAT model; carbon emissions; regional differences; economic development
Abstract: With ever-increasing problems of resource and environment, carbon emissions and its regional differences have attracted academic attention. This paper uses extended STIRPAT model and principal component analysis method on the basis of analyzing carbon emissions of 29 provinces in China from during the stage of 1995-2007 to analyze the impact of population size, population structure, level of economic development, energy intensity factors to carbon emissions. The results show that: the impact of different provinces' population size and structure and level of economic development to carbon emissions is the same in dynamic trend, but the degree of influence is different; in energy intensity, the impact trend of different provinces is different, changes of energy intensity in some provinces cause by rising in carbon emissions. Thus, the regulations and policies of energy saving and emissions reduction should be adapted to local conditions and avoid to be across the board.

Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network

Abstract: Today, listed companies sharing or holding financial enterprises to build industry-based financial holding company, and before or after the formation, its property boundary changes occurred. In this context, using the data envelopment analysis method, the article will construct a property type of boundary changing efficiency evaluation system of industry-based financial holding listed company for the listed enterprises which share or hold companies from 2001 to 2009. The empirical results show that, industry-based financial holding company operational efficiency reduces after the enterprise Boundary changing. And at the same time, the financial companies sharing differently show different features. So in the process of sharing, the listed companies should be careful entering and effectively guard against financial risks.
