Article Title: The Key to Understanding Marxist Economic Doctrine - On Understanding of Marx's Concept of Estranged Labor
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: estrangement; estranged labor; materialist conception of history
Abstract: Estranged labor is the starting point in the critique of political economics. Marx illustrates the essence of estrangement by starting out from an actual economic fact. By proceeding from the phenomenon that the products produced by the laborers are extracted by the bourgeoisie and that the proletariat is in the impoverished situation, Marx analyzes the issue of estranged labor, and then proceeding from estranged labor, he scientifically illustrates all the categories of political economics. Therefore, understanding the concept of estranged labor put forward by Marx is the key to understanding Marxist economic doctrine.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low carbon economy; new type industrialization; government industrial policy; guidance
Abstract: Under the dual requirement of economic development and ecological environment protection, low carbon economy has become a choice model of economic development for countries around the world. The development of new type industrialization is most crucial for the development of low carbon economy, and the leading of government industrial policies plays the most important role to the starting of new type Industrialization. The government industrial policies can give guidance in many aspects, such as planning industrial development, taxes, subsidies, government direct investments, perfecting supporting facilities, and etc.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: Valuating Privacy with Option Pricing Theory
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: One of the key challenges in the information society is responsible handling of personal data. An often-cited reason why people fail to make rational decisions regarding their own informational privacy is the high uncertainty about future consequences of information disclosures today. This chapter builds an analogy to financial options and draws on principles of option pricing to account for this uncertainty in the valuation of privacy. For this purpose, the development of a data subject's personal attributes over time and the development of the attribute distribution in the population are modeled as two stochastic processes, which fit into the Binomial Option Pricing Model (BOPM). Possible applications of such valuation methods to guide decision support in future privacy-enhancing technologies (PETs) are sketched.

Author Keywords: fiduciary duties; director; creditor; corporation act 2001
Abstract: In this paper, there are altogether four ways responding to the commentary of Dillon L.J who advocates that directors owe duty of care to the company, but not to the creditors. First of all, it confirms that directors stand in fiduciary relationship to company. Secondly, by referring to the precedents and traditional theories, it then explains whether the directors owe fiduciary duties to creditors or not. Finally, this paper suggests the creditor's protection under Corporations Act 2001 band other possible statutory measures for creditors when the fiduciary duty is uncertain to be established.

We should learn from advanced foreign experience and improve our public investment on rural infrastructure.

Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low carbon economy; development; media support
Abstract: Given the background of global climatic change, the low carbon economy in China is an inevitable choice to deal with contradictions between economy development and population, resources, and environment. The low carbon economy, however, is an economical development mode of high level when the economy grows in a certain phase. It needs not only the support of a high innovative technology and the promotion of a relatively perfect policy system, but the elevation of people's awareness on low carbon economy that may form a common view to be put it into practice. In this paper, the media support countermeasures for low carbon economy development are proposed, from building low carbon concept, advocating living style of low carbon to perfecting incentive system of low carbon market by information spreading.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: The Impact of Climate on Work Values: A Comparison of Cold, Warm, and Hot Regions in China
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: regional differences; work values; climate; China
Keywords Plus: BEHAVIOR; PERFORMANCE; DIMENSIONS; VIOLENCE; CULTURE; MOOD
Abstract: A comparison among Chinese employees in three different climatic areas revealed different scores on four work values of Hofstede's model. With regard to power distance, temperate regions showed greater scores than colder-than-temperate and hotter-than-temperate regions. In terms of masculinity, the results showed that temperate regions have greater scores than colder-than-temperate and hotter-than-temperate regions. Regarding collectivism, hotter-than-temperate regions also showed a higher collectivism score than did colder-than-temperate regions. With regard to uncertainty avoidance, temperate regions showed greater scores than colder-than-temperate and hotter-than-temperate regions, even though colder-than-temperate and hotter-than-temperate regions did not present any significant differences. The results from this article show that China should not be considered as a homogeneous market and suggest that multinational corporations(MNCs) need to take differentiated management strategies across regions in China.

Article Title: On the Developmental Mechanism of Sci-tech Talent in China - based on low-carbon economic development
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low-carbon economy; sci-tech talent; developmental mechanism
Abstract: The core of the low-carbon economic development is the science and technology innovation, and the key of this innovation is talents. Therefore, the study on the developmental mechanism of sci-tech talents has great significance on low-carbon economic development in China. Starting with the connotation of low-carbon economy and sci-tech (science and technology) talent, this paper analyzes the status of the sci-tech talent development in China based on low-carbon economic development, and summarizes the problems associated with low-carbon economic development as well. The paper proposes the sci-tech talent development in China based on low-carbon economic development should establish a sound market mechanism, implement a proper employment mechanism, introduce a scientific competition mechanism, use a reasonable incentive mechanism, and explore the robust service mechanism.

Article Title: On the State Economic Regulation Power and its Operation
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: economic laws; state power; state economic regulation
Abstract: The state economic regulation power is a form of state power that is different from the administrative power. It arises simultaneously with the appearance of the state economic regulation function. The exertion of it should follow such principles as the principles of legal regulation, democratic regulation, economic benefit, social benefit, and compliance with international economic regulations. The development and change of its actual exertion modes depend on the specific types of market imperfections. And it is fundamentally constrained by the social citizen's economic rights. Therefore, we should build the related legal systems to maintain the social citizen's basic economic rights, and establish related participation and supervision systems for social citizens.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: Analyze and identify factors affecting students matriculate loss
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: school; matriculate loss
Abstract: From the perspective of service, products schools provide for students are homogeneous, the potential loss of students is possible. Because the students choose schools with great freedom, and can transfer at any time. The competition between schools is essentially the struggle to win students, but also competition to retain the potential students may transfer. Therefore, how to keep the old students and discourage their intent to transfer is of great importance for schools. This paper analyzes and identifies the factors that affect the loss of students, including: teaching geography, teaching environment, teachers, learning content, teaching methods, teaching attitude, grades, tuition charges. The loss of students is due to one of these eight factors, in single factor or multiple factors, individually or jointly effects.

Article Title: Research on the Development of Industrial Clusters of Hunan Province
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: Hunan province; industrial development; industrial cluster; global value chain
Abstract: As an agricultural province, Hunan has been promoting its industrialization process. On the basis of its original industrial development, Hunan's industrial clusters have been developing rapidly which were pushed by promoting policies and accompanied by the industrial transferring from the eastern region to the central and western region in China. Some industrial clusters have become the pillars of regional economy, and played an important role in the process of upgrading and adjustment of industrial structure. This paper analyzes the development status, advantages and disadvantages of industrial clusters in Hunan Province, and put forward the developing priorities and countermeasures for the future development of these clusters.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: Research on Risk Management of Breakthrough Technological Innovation
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: breakthrough technological innovation; risk management; risk factors; pre-control measures
Abstract: Since the 1990s, the trend of companies implementing technological innovation has accelerated so that people pay more attention to new technology development modes, known as breakthrough technological innovation, which is completely different from incremental technological innovation of the past. In this paper, we note risk management is important and necessary in the process of breakthrough technological innovation. First of all, according to previous studies, we come to the definition and features of breakthrough technological innovation, compared to incremental innovation. Moreover, combined with internal and external environment and the characteristics of breakthrough technological innovation, the risk components of breakthrough technological innovation are divided into six categories. Third, in response to these risk factors, we analyze five areas, such as attitude of decision makers towards risk, enterprise's structure, information management systems, market strategy, and motivation mechanisms of staff. Furthermore, this paper recommends a series of pre-control measures to enterprises. Above all, risk management can be used for reference by companies and industries to break away from the dilemma related to breakthrough technological innovation and to realize efficient sustainable development.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low-carbon; agriculture; mode; greenhouse gas; climate change
Abstract: Agriculture and global climate change are interrelated. On the one hand, climate change has influenced on agriculture; on the other hand, agriculture is an important source of greenhouse gas emissions. It is the urgent task that how to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and enhance the capacity for coping with climate change in agriculture, and achieve sustainable development of agriculture ultimately. In this paper, the author firstly describes the necessity of developing low-carbon agriculture in China, and then analyses the present cyclic mode of low-carbon agricultural development, which the government has explored in Anhui Province. Finally, the author tries to put forward some pieces of advice to develop low-carbon agriculture in China based on learning from and draw on experience of developing low-carbon agriculture in Taiwan.

Abstract: Not only do tourists often become the biggest victims of tourism ecological safety accidents, but also the tourists' safety quality may be a major factor that affects the extent of the damage of accidents. This article builds a safety management system in the horizon of the tourists' safety quality from the implementation of strategy, the mechanisms of elements, the supporting systems and the operating framework. By making the tourists' safety quality and many resources outside scenic spots into the tourism ecological safety management system, the author hopes to broaden the safety management vision and improve the safety management level of scenic spots.

Article Title: Effects of short sale constraints on information efficiency
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: short sale constraints; information efficiency; decision tree
Abstract: This paper introduces the mode of Diamond and Verrecchia(1987) to extend the initial model under the condition of non-short sale constraints in order to study the effects of short sale constraints on market efficiency. As is found in the study, the informed trader determines whether to carry on the short sale trade according to the degree of short sale constraints. Besides, given the same information distribution, too much extent of short sale constraints would not contribute to the release of information, which then exerts negative influence on information efficiency of the market. In addition, the study also finds out that the process during which the market achieves a state of efficiency is dynamic.

Authors: Shetty, N; Schwartz, G; Felegyhazi, M; Walrand, J
Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Author Full Names: Shetty, Nikhil; Schwartz, Galina; Felegyhazi, Mark; Walrand, Jean
Article Title: Competitive Cyber-Insurance and Internet Security
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: This paper investigates how competitive cyber-insurers affect network security and welfare of the networked society. In our model, a user's probability to incur damage (from being attacked) depends on both his security and the network security, with the latter taken by individual users as given. First, we consider cyber-insurers who cannot observe (and thus, affect) individual user security. This asymmetric information causes moral hazard. Then, for most parameters, no equilibrium exists: the insurance market is missing. Even if an equilibrium exists, the insurance contract covers only a minor fraction of the damage; network security worsens relative to the no-insurance equilibrium. Second, we consider insurers with perfect information about their users' security. Here, user security is perfectly enforceable (zero cost); each insurance contract stipulates the required user security. The unique equilibrium contract covers the entire user damage. Still, for most parameters, network security worsens relative to the no-insurance equilibrium. Although cyber-insurance improves user welfare, in general, competitive cyber-insurers fail to improve network security.

Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: This chapter applies real options analytic framework to firms' investment activity in information security technology and then a dynamic analysis of information security investment is explored by extending Gordon-Loeb (2002). The current research provides how firms have to respond to immediate or remote threat numerically. It shows that although positive drift of threat causes both larger and later investment expenditure, negative drift causes immediate investment and lower investment expenditure. The efficiency of vulnerability reduction technology encourages firms to invest earlier and induces cost reduction. To know the form of vulnerability is important because the effect of high vulnerability on timing and amount of the investment expenditure is mixed.

Article Title: Analysis on Barriers and Strategies of Private Enterprises' Independent Innovation
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: private enterprise; independent innovation; barrier; strategy
Abstract: Independent innovation is the following link of enterprise realizing technological breakthrough through its own effort and based on this, impetus technological innovation depends upon own ability, the innovative activities of completing technical commercialization and gaining commercial profits. The innovation is a social economy process, besides restricted by technical factors, the system environment is also an important attribute deciding innovation success or failure. There are four primary aspects affecting the private enterprise independent innovation behavior: innovation power, innovation risk, innovation ability and innovation financing. They affect the wish of private enterprise independent innovation, and decide private enterprise independent innovation behavior.

Article Title: A Study of Short Selling's Influence on Stock Market Volatility in China
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: volatility; short selling; non-parametric test
Abstract: On the basis of the comparison between the volatility of the Shanghai Composite Index before launch of short selling and the volatility after launch, this paper draws a conclusion that the volatility does not significantly increase after the introduction of short selling. In addition, the volatility model advanced by Hardouvelis and Theodosiou (2001) is used to study the day volatility. The results further confirm the above conclusion.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: The Policy Maker's Anguish: Regulating Personal Data Behavior Between Paradoxes and Dilemmas
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: Regulators in Europe and elsewhere are paying great attention to identity, privacy and trust in online and converging environments. Appropriate regulation of identity in a ubiquitous information environment is seen as one of the major drivers of the future Internet economy. Regulation of personal identity data has come to the fore including mapping conducted on digital personhood by the OECD; work on human rights and profiling by the Council of Europe and major studies by the European Commission with regard to self-regulation in the privacy market, electronic identity technical interoperability and enhanced safety for young people. These domains overlap onto an increasingly complex model of regulation of individuals' identity management, online and offline. This chapter argues that policy makers struggle to deal with issues concerning electronic identity, due to the apparently irrational and unpredictable behavior of users when engaging in online interactions involving identity management. Building on empirical survey evidence from four EU countries, we examine the first aspect in detail citizens' management of identity in a digital environment. We build on data from a large scale (n = 5,265) online survey of attitudes to electronic identity among young Europeans (France, Germany, Spain, UK) conducted in August 2008. The survey asked questions about perceptions and acceptance of risks, general motivations, attitudes and behaviors concerning electronic identity. Four behavioral paradoxes are identified in the analysis: a privacy paradox (to date well known), but also a control paradox, a responsibility paradox and an awareness paradox. The chapter then examines the paradoxes in relation of three main policy dilemmas framing the debate on digital identity. The paper concludes by arguing for an expanded identity debate spanning policy circles and the engineering community.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Author Full Names: Luo, Huawei; Chen, Yun; Zhang, Hua
Article Title: Evaluation on Land Ecological Security in Chengdu
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: land ecological security; evaluation; Chengdu
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to study the trend of land ecological security in Chengdu. In this paper, improved entropy method, multi-objective comprehensive evaluation method and coordination degree model are applied to evaluate land ecological security from 1998 to 2007 in Chengdu. The results show that land ecological security in Chengdu gets better in general, but the variation is small; economic factors play an important role in Chengdu land ecological security; coordination relations between four subsystems of Chengdu land ecological security system are instable. Following a discussion of these challenges, this paper proposes some reasonable suggestions to deal with them.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: Modeling the Economic Incentives of DDoS Attacks: Femtocell Case Study
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: Many of the Internet security incidents are caused by agents which act moved by economic incentives. When that is the case, it is possible to model attacker's incentives by applying economics principles and, if we can collect appropriate data, we can use the model to have a better understanding of the risk imposed by these threats. This paper presents a simple model that represents the economic incentives for launching DDoS attacks against a specific telecommunications service. In addition, some data has been collected in order to quantify some of the variables of the model. Finally, some simulations have been performed to have a better knowledge of the risk of suffering this kind of attacks and propose solutions to mitigate it.

Article Title: The Road to China's Neotype Industrialization: Developing Low-carbon Economy
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low-carbon economy; China's neotype industrialization; sustainable development; energy conservation and emission reduction
Abstract: After the United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009 hold in Copenhagen, the international community gradually reached a consensus that developing low-carbon economy is the inevitable choice to respond to climate change. Developing low-carbon economy is the way to harmonize development of society, economy and environment. And it is also the important means of realizing sustainable development. Based on the such troubles in economic development of china as the large population, fast economic growth with huge consumption of energy, this paper emphasizes the necessity and urgency of developing a low carbon economy, points out that new-type industrialization with Chinese characteristics can be achieved only by developing low-carbon economy. Moreover, according to previous studies, we come to the definition and development goals of low-carbon economy. Furthermore, in line with the definition of low-carbon economy, we analyze the present situation of development of low-carbon economy in China. At last, this paper focuses on analyzing from macro level to micro level, and from nation, industries, to individuals, to provides some reference for devise measures of promoting low carbon economy.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: Low-carbon Economy and the Confucian Ethics
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low-carbon economy; Confucian ethics; consummating oneself and consummating the nature
Abstract: The chief aim of low-carbon economy theory is to resolve the contradiction between the economic system and the ecosystem, as a result, economic, technological, and institutional problems have been taken care of particularly. However, in the real world with low-carbon economy development involved in complex relationships, Pareto Optimum can't be reached. Actually, to develop low-carbon economy not just to develop low-carbon industries and it is government and enterprise's duty, meanwhile it needs full participation of every citizen. Low -carbon economy should be expressed by a behavior, a philosophy or ethics. Confucian ethics of 'consummating oneself and consummating the nature' and philosophy of 'unity of heaven and men' offer us a guiding principle which man can follow to harmonize his relations with nature and to solve ecological danger, and it can be used as the reference for studying low-carbon economy.

Article Title: Researches on the experience authenticity of the rural tourist based on the fuzzy assessments
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: rural tourists; experience authenticity; fuzzy comprehensive assessment; Changsha
Abstract: In this paper, the fuzzy comprehensive assessment model of the authenticity of the rural tourist experience is firstly constructed. This paper then takes Changsha for example and uses this model to conduct the quantitative calculation and analysis on the data obtained through the survey on the authenticity of rural tourist experience. According to the calculation result, the rural tourists give the higher authenticity assessment on their rural experience about the rural scenery, air quality, rural specialties. While they give the lower authenticity assessment on the local architecture styles, DIY producing, participation in recreational farming, rural tourism explanation, the waiter's dress, etc. According to the results of the development status quo of rural tourism in Changsha, this paper puts forward the corresponding countermeasures and suggestions to the development of rural tourism which can provide the decision-making and reference on rural tourism development in Changsha and also is good for the sustainable development of the rural tourism in Changsha.

Authors: Frei, S; Schatzmann, D; Plattner, B; Trammell, B
Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Author Full Names: Frei, Stefan; Schatzmann, Dominik; Plattner, Bernhard; Trammell, Brian
Article Title: Modeling the Security Ecosystem - The Dynamics of (In)Security
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: The security of information technology and computer networks is effected by a wide variety of actors and processes which together make up a security ecosystem; here we examine this ecosystem, consolidating many aspects of security that have hitherto been discussed only separately. First, we analyze the roles of the major actors within this ecosystem and the processes they participate in, and the the paths vulnerability data take through the ecosystem and the impact of each of these on security risk. Then, based on a quantitative examination of 27,000 vulnerabilities disclosed over the past decade and taken from publicly available data sources, we quantify the systematic gap between exploit and patch availability. We provide the first examination of the impact and the risks associated with this gap on the ecosystem as a whole. Our analysis provides a metric for the success of the responsible disclosure process. We measure the prevalence of the commercial markets for vulnerability information and highlight the role of security information providers (SIP), which function as the free press of the ecosystem.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: Potential Rating Indicators for Cyberinsurance: An Exploratory Qualitative Study
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: In this paper we present the results of an exploratory qualitative study with experts. The aim of the study was the identification of potential rating variables which could be used to calculate a premium for Cyberinsurance coverages. For this purpose we have conducted semi-structured qualitative interviews with a sample of 36 experts from the DACH I region. The gathered statements have been consolidated and further reduced to a subset of indicators which are available and difficult to manipulate. The reduced set of indicators has been presented again to the 36 experts in order to rank them according to their relative importance. In this paper we describe the results of this exploratory qualitative study and conclude by discussing implications of our findings for both research and practice.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: The Risk of Risk Analysis And its Relation to the Economics of Insider Threats
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: Insider threats to organizational information security are widely viewed as an important concern, but little is understood as to the pattern of their occurrence. We outline an argument for explaining what originally surprised us: that many practitioners report that their organizations take basic steps to prevent insider attacks, but do not attempt to address more serious attacks. We suggest that an understanding of the true cost of additional policies to control insider threats, and the dynamic nature of potential insider threats together help explain why this observed behavior is economically rational. This conclusion also suggests that further work needs to be done to understand how better to change underlying motivations of insiders, rather than simply focus on controlling and monitoring their behavior.

Article Title: On the Right to Financial Development of Rural Market Players
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: rural market player; right to financial development; coordination of rural and urban development
Abstract: The coordination of rural and urban development needs to endow rural market players with equal right to financial development. The right to financial development of rural market players refers to the right that rural financial demand subjects enjoy direct or indirect national supportive financial services to meet basic needs of survival and development or equal opportunities for competition. General definition of the right to financial development of rural market players may start from the correct grasp of its nature, subjects, objects and contents. The realization and guarantee of the right to financial development of rural market players are indispensable to the democratization and standardization of the national regulation of rural finance.

Book Editors: Moore, T; Pym, DJ; Ioannidis, C
Article Title: Security Economics and Critical National Infrastructure
Source Title: ECONOMICS OF INFORMATION SECURITY AND PRIVACY
Conference Title: 8th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security
Abstract: There has been considerable effort and expenditure since 9/11 on the protection of 'Critical National Infrastructure' against online attack. This is commonly interpreted to mean preventing online sabotage against utilities such as electricity, oil and gas, water, and sewage including pipelines, refineries, generators, storage depots and transport facilities such as tankers and terminals. A consensus is emerging that the protection of such assets is more a matter of business models and regulation in short, of security economics than of technology. We describe the problems, and the state of play, in this paper. Industrial control systems operate in a different world from systems previously studied by security economists; we find the same issues (lock-in, externalities, asymmetric information and so on) but in different forms. Lock-in is physical, rather than based on network effects, while the most serious externalities result from correlated failure, whether from cascade failures, common-mode failures or simultaneous attacks. There is also an interesting natural experiment happening, in that the USA is regulating cyber security in the electric power industry, but not in oil and gas, while the UK is not regulating at all but rather encouraging industry's own efforts. Some European governments are intervening, while others are leaving cybersecurity entirely to plant owners to worry about. We already note some perverse effects of the U.S. regulation regime as companies game the system, to the detriment of overall dependability.

Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network

Abstract: In this paper, apply co-integration analysis and the classical Granger causality test and the non-classical Granger causality test based on error-correct model on the degree of economic duality and the economic growth rate of Guangdong from 1978-2008. The conclusion: the co-integration relationship is revealed between the two variables, there is a unidirectional Granger causality relationship from the degree of economic duality and the economic growth rate in long term, and a bidirectional Granger causality relationship in short term. Article Title: Thinking on Management of Bank Loans for Colleges and Universities
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: colleges and universities; bank loans; management
Abstract: With the continuous deepening of higher education system and the development of market economy, and in a shortage of government input in higher education, bank loans actively promotes the rapid development of colleges and universities, and has huge impacts on the financial management of colleges and universities. Main problems about the management of bank loans for colleges and universities are excessive growth in size, oversimplified decision-making process, impractical repayment plan, and non-standard uses. Main reasons are the lack of risk awareness and responsibility awareness in colleges and universities, management lag of education authorities, and lax bank supervision. Colleges and universities shall raise awareness and strengthen loan management while education authorities shall strengthen supervision, and banks shall strengthen monitoring.

Article Title: The Spillover Effects of International R&D and Strategic Trade Policy
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: the ex antes subsidy; post tax; spillover effect; strategic trade policy
Abstract: Based on the research of Spencer and Brander (1983) and d'Aspremont and Jacquemin (1988), the paper constructs a three-stage game model and analyzes the subsidy measures upon firms' R&D activities under the context of strategic trade policy. The result indicates that when international spillover effects of R&D activities are at a relatively high level, governments need to impose the ex ante subsidy for domestic firms' R&D activities; When spillover effects at a very high level, governments should carry out the combination of the ex ante subsidy and post tax policy.

Article Title: Selection of Eco-leading Industrial Park
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: eco-oriented industry; industrial park; principal component analysis
Abstract: Based on the development orientation of eco-industries, this paper takes Changsha Huang Xing National Eco-Industrial Demonstration Park as an example to analyze the selection indicators and methods of eco-oriented industries. Via empirical study mentioned above, the study obtains development priority orders of the industrial park, and brings forth development orientation of eco-oriented industries allowing for eco-park's actual situation. The outcome provides theoretical supports for coordinated development of eco-industries and the leading industries in this industrial park.

Authors: Feng, L; Liu, Y; Zhao, XD
Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Author Full Names: Feng, Lei; Liu, Yan; Zhao, Xiaodan
Article Title: New Rural Construction in the Era of Low-carbon Economy
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: Low-carbon economy; New rural construction; Planning and designing; Energy conservation
Abstract: Low-carbon economy has become the theme of the era; and the era background and connotation of low-carbon economy was elaborated. In view of the relationship between low-carbon economy and the construction of new socialist countryside, the problems currently existing in the new rural construction such as inadequate understanding about the new rural construction, the imperfect establishment of new rural culture system, negligence of the protection and heritage of rural landscape, were analyzed. The requirement and strategy of new rural construction in the low-carbon economy era were put forward.

Article Title: Research on the connotative definition and evaluation system of new-style industrialization with Chinese characteristics
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: evaluation system; New-style Industrialization; comprehensive index method
Abstract: Based on the summarization of the research achievements at home and abroad, the connotation and characteristics of the new-style industrialized way with Chinese characteristics was defined. From the Angle of evaluation of the process of industrialization of new-style industrialized way with Chinese characteristics, and review the current academic achievement evaluation system of innovation, and put forward index system which is composed by 8 categories that are economic development, innovation environment, technological progress, structural changes, comprehensive benefits, resource utilization, green manufacturing and human resources. Adopt comprehensive index method that the evaluation index of industrialization and the results are analyzed, and puts forward the corresponding countermeasures.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: The Low-Carbon Resonance from Oriental Philosophy: On Daoist Wisdom for Harmonious Development
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: low-carbon; climate change; Daoism; harmonious development; East Asia
Abstract: The twenty-first century has witnessed climate changes on a global scale and led us into low-carbon era. Daoism, the aboriginal ancient civilization of East Asia, illuminates the issue with its primitive eco-philosophy. In this paper, I will examine the interconnection between Daoist thoughts and the low-carbon economy. Seen through the lens of Daoism's ideas of holism and wuwei, harmonious development in East Asia will be discussed in aspects of both metaphysical roots and practical urgency. Additionally, the Daoist principle of moderation might offer an antidote to several ethic dilemmas and offer guidelines for creating a balanced economy. Despite some restrictions of Daoism's particular cultural perspective, this paper attempts to use oriental tradition in search of a more harmonious global world.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: An Empirical Analysis of China's Industrial Product Import Effects of Environmental Regulations
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: environmental regulations; import cost effect; import innovation effect; empirical test
Abstract: Based on an empirical analysis of the relevant data from 1990 to 2007, the paper draws two results: 1.There is a long-term co-integration relationship between the intensity of environmental regulations and the industrial pollutant import, and the former imposes a significant negative impact on the latter, so China's industrial product import cost effect exists; 2. There is not a long-term co-integration relationship between the intensity of environmental regulations and the industrial product import, so China's industrial product import innovation effect does not exist. As a result, investment on industry to control pollutants and strengthen management on pollutants should be increased.

Book Editors: Chen, WJ; Liao, XP; Zhu, YL
Article Title: Evaluation Research on the Construction Level of Two-oriented Society in Central Region
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: central region; two-oriented society; evaluation indicator system
Abstract: The development of two-oriented society is of great significance to the rising of central region and transformation of China's economic growth mode. An evaluation indicator system for the construction of two-oriented society needs to be established to evaluate the effectiveness of comprehensive supporting reform test zone for construction of two-oriented society in Wuhan City Circle and Chang-Zhu-Tan Urban Agglomeration, in combination with empirical analysis on the current status of construction of two-oriented society in six provinces in central region based on relevant data. The results show that the relation between economic development and resource conservation & environmental-friendly is negative, namely economy develops with the cost of wasting of resources and environmental damage. While the government's active intervention is necessary for the realization of cooperative development between economic development and resource conservation & environmental-friendly.

Article Title: Yangtze River Delta Region Comparative Analysis of Innovation Efficiency--An Empirical Study Based on Panel Data
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: Regional Innovation; Innovation Efficiency; Yangtze River Delta Region
Abstract: From the perspective of regional innovation efficiency, this paper selects Shanghai, Jiangsu and Zhejiang Provinces in China as the research object. Through comparing the innovation efficiency in the three regions, it aims to reflect the development condition of regional innovations, and assess their regional innovation performances. The innovation resources and outputs in Shanghai are both far ahead. But the innovation performances of Jiangsu and Zhejiang are not satisfactory. The different characteristics of innovation development in Yangtze River Delta, means that the development of innovation in Yangtze River Delta as a whole should complement with each other, strengthen the regional innovation cooperation, and avoid vicious competition and duplication.

Article Title: Behavioral Agency Theory Based on Inequity Aversion
Source Title: ADVANCES IN ASIA-PACIFIC LOW CARBON ECONOMY
Conference Title: International Conference of Asia-Pacific Low Carbon Economy/9th Northeast Asia Academic Network
Author Keywords: inequity aversion; behavioral agency theory; utility function
Abstract: This paper proposes the shortcoming of traditional agency theory in the view of social preference, and concludes three main contents that are neglected in the process of establishing current Behavioral Agency Theory. The utility function doesn't take the main body heterogeneity into account. The relationship between inequity aversion and risk aversion isn't considered in behavioral agency, and behavioral agency model hasn't been examined by the experiment. Finally, behavioral agency theory and its directions for research and application have been put forwarded.

Authors: Attar, A; Mariotti, T; Salanié, F
Author Full Names: Attar, Andrea; Mariotti, Thomas; Salanie, Francois
Article Title: Nonexclusive Competition in the Market for Lemons
Author Keywords: Adverse selection; competing mechanisms; nonexclusivity
Keywords Plus: COMMON-AGENCY GAMES; ADVERSE SELECTION; INSURANCE MARKETS; ASYMMETRIC INFORMATION; MORAL HAZARD; SECURITY DESIGN; CONTRACTS; LIQUIDITY; REVELATION; PRINCIPLE
Abstract: A seller can trade an endowment of a perfectly divisible good, the quality of which she privately knows. Buyers compete by offering menus of nonexclusive contracts, so that the seller can privately trade with several buyers. In this setting, we show that an equilibrium exists under mild conditions and that aggregate equilibrium allocations are generically unique. Although the good for sale is divisible, in equilibrium the seller ends up trading her whole endowment or not trading at all. Trades take place at a price equal to the expected quality of the good, conditional on the seller being ready to trade at that price. Our model thus provides a novel strategic foundation for Akerlof's (1970) results. It also contrasts with competitive screening models in which contracts are assumed to be exclusive, as in Rothschild and Stiglitz (1976). Latent contracts that are issued but not traded in equilibrium play an important role in our analysis.

Article Title: A risk-based model for the valuation of pension insurance
Author Keywords: Pension insurance; PBGC; Defined benefit plan; Correlation; Sponsor support
Abstract: in the US, defined benefit plans are insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). Taking account of the fact that the PBGC covers only the residual deficits of the pension fund the sponsoring company is unable to cover and that the plans can be prematurely terminated, we consider a model that accounts for the joint dynamics of the pension fund's and sponsoring firm's assets in order to effectively determine the risk-based pension premium for the insurance provided by the PBGC. We obtain a closed-form pricing formula for this risk-based premium. Its magnitude depends highly on the investment portfolio of the pension fund and of the sponsoring company as well as the correlation between these two portfolios. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Second order regular variation and conditional tail expectation of multiple risks
Author Keywords: Second order approximation; Value at risk; Conditional tail expectation; Asymptotic analysis; Sub-extremal multiple risk
Abstract: For the purpose of risk management, the study of tail behavior of multiple risks is more relevant than the study of their overall distributions. Asymptotic study assuming that each marginal risk goes to infinity is more mathematically tractable and has also uncovered some interesting performance of risk measures and relationships between risk measures by their first order approximations. However, the First order approximation is only a crude way to understand tail behavior of multiple risks, and especially for sub-extremal risks. In this paper, we conduct asymptotic analysis on conditional tail expectation (CTE) under the condition of second order regular variation (2RV). First, the closed-form second order approximation of CTE is obtained for the univariate case. Then CTE of the form E vertical bar X-1 vertical bar g(X-1, ..., X-d) > t], as t -> infinity. is studied, where g is a loss aggregating function and (X-1, ..., X-d) := (RT1, ..., RTd) with R independent of (T-1, ..., T-d) and the survivor function of R satisfying the condition of 2RV. Closed-form second order approximations of CTE for this multivariate form have been derived in terms of corresponding value at risk. For both the univariate and multivariate cases, we find that the first order approximation is affected by only the regular variation index -alpha of marginal survivor functions, while the second order approximation is influenced by both the parameters for first and second order regular variation, and the rate of convergence to the first order approximation is dominated by the second order parameter only. We have also shown that the 2RV condition and the assumptions for the multivariate form are satisfied by many parametric distribution families, and thus the closed-form approximations would be useful for applications. Those closed-form results extend the study of Zhu and Li (submitted for publication). (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: ASYMPTOTIC BEHAVIOR OF THE CUSUM OF SQUARES TEST UNDER STOCHASTIC AND DETERMINISTIC TIME TRENDS
Abstract: We generalize the cumulative sum of squares (CUSQ) test to the case of nonstationary autoregressive distributed lag models with deterministic time trends. The test may be implemented with either ordinary least squares residuals or standardized forecast errors. In explosive cases the asymptotic theory applies more generally for the least squares residuals-based test. Preliminary simulations of the tests suggest a very modest difference between the tests and a very modest variation with nuisance parameters. This supports the use of the tests in explorative analysis.

Article Title: HIGHER-ORDER ACCURATE, POSITIVE SEMIDEFINITE ESTIMATION OF LARGE-SAMPLE COVARIANCE AND SPECTRAL DENSITY MATRICES
Keywords Plus: MINIMAX ADAPTIVE ESTIMATION; BANDWIDTH SELECTION; HETEROSKEDASTICITY; CONSISTENT; INFERENCE
Abstract: A new class of large-sample covariance and spectral density matrix estimators is proposed based on the notion of flat-top kernels. The new estimators are shown to be higher-order accurate when higher-order accuracy is possible. A discussion on kernel choice is presented as well as a supporting finite-sample simulation. The problem of spectral estimation under a potential lack of finite fourth moments is also addressed. The higher-order accuracy of flat-top kernel estimators typically comes at the sacrifice of the positive semidefinite property. Nevertheless, we show how a flattop estimator can be modified to become positive semidefinite (even strictly positive definite) while maintaining its higher-order accuracy. In addition, an easy (and consistent) procedure for optimal bandwidth choice is given; this procedure estimates the optimal bandwidth associated with each individual element of the target matrix, automatically sensing (and adapting to) the underlying correlation structure.

Authors: Broeders, D; Chen, A; Koos, B
Author Full Names: Broeders, Dirk; Chen, An; Koos, Birgit
Article Title: A utility-based comparison of pension funds and life insurance companies under regulatory constraints
Author Keywords: Pension plans; Annuities; Barrier options; Contingent claim approach; Certainty equivalents
Keywords Plus: MARKET VALUE; CONDITIONAL INDEXATION; SURPLUS DISTRIBUTION; WITH-PROFIT; LIABILITIES; RISK; GUARANTEES; VALUATION; POLICIES; OPTION
Abstract: This paper compares two different types of annuity providers, i.e. defined benefit pension funds and life insurance companies. One of the key differences is that the residual risk in pension funds is collectively borne by the beneficiaries and the sponsor's shareholders while in the case of life insurers it is borne by the external shareholders. First, this paper employs a contingent claim approach to evaluate the risk return tradeoff for annuitants. For that, we take into account the differences in contract specifications and in regulatory regimes. Second, a welfare analysis is conducted to examine whether a consumer with power utility experiences utility gains if she chooses a defined benefit plan or a life annuity contract over a defined contribution plan. We demonstrate that regulation can be designed to support a level playing field amongst different financial institutions. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: ON RATE OPTIMALITY FOR ILL-POSED INVERSE PROBLEMS IN ECONOMETRICS
Keywords Plus: INSTRUMENTAL VARIABLE ESTIMATION; MODELS; REGULARIZATION; CONVERGENCE
Abstract: In this paper we clarify the relations between the existing sets of regularity conditions for convergence rates of nonparametric indirect regression (NPIR) and nonparametric instrumental variables (NPIV) regression models. We establish minimax risk lower bounds in mean integrated squared error loss for the NPIR and NPIV models under two basic regularity conditions: the approximation number and the link condition. We show that both a simple projection estimator for the NPIR model and a sieve minimum distance estimator for the NPIV model can achieve the minimax risk lower bounds and are rate optimal uniformly over a large class of structure functions, allowing for mildly ill-posed and severely ill-posed cases.

Article Title: ON THE COMPLETENESS CONDITION IN NONPARAMETRIC INSTRUMENTAL PROBLEMS
Keywords Plus: SIMULTANEOUS-EQUATIONS MODELS; ERRORS-IN-VARIABLES; LOCATION FAMILIES; IDENTIFICATION
Abstract: The notion of completeness between two random elements has been considered recently to provide identification in nonparametric instrumental problems. This condition is quite abstract, however, and characterizations have been obtained only in special cases. This paper considers a nonparametric model between the two variables with an additive separability and a large support condition. In this framework, different versions of completeness are obtained, depending on which regularity conditions are imposed. This result allows one to establish identification in an instrumental nonparametric regression with limited endogenous regressor, a case where the control variate approach breaks down.

Article Title: Corrigendum to Resource-monotonicity for house allocation problems
Author Keywords: Corrigendum; Indivisible objects; Resource-monotonicity
Abstract: Ehlers and Klaus (Int J Game Theory 32:545-560, 2003) study so-called allocation problems and claim to characterize all rules satisfying efficiency, independence of irrelevant objects, and resource-monotonicity on two preference domains (Ehlers and Klaus 2003, Theorem 1). They explicitly prove Theorem 1 for preference domain R-0 which requires that the null object is always the worst object and mention that the corresponding proofs for the larger domain Rf unrestricted preferences are completely analogous. In Example 1 and Lemma 1, this corrigendum provides a counterexample to Ehlers and Klaus (2003, Theorem 1) on the general domain R We also propose a way of correcting the result on the general domain R by strengthening independence of irrelevant objects: in addition to requiring that the chosen allocation should depend only on preferences over the set of available objects (which always includes the null object), we add a situation in which the allocation should also be invariant when preferences over the null object change. Finally, we offer a short proof of the corrected result that uses the established result of Theorem 1 for the restricted domain R-0.

Authors: Nam, HS; Tang, QH; Yang, F
Author Full Names: Nam, Hee Seok; Tang, Qihe; Yang, Fan
Article Title: Characterization of upper comonotonicity via tail convex order
Author Keywords: Comonotonicity; Upper comonotonicity; Tail convex order; Haezendonck risk measures
Abstract: In this paper, we show a characterization of upper comonotonicity via tail convex order. For any given marginal distributions, a maximal random vector with respect to tail convex order is proved to be upper comonotonic under suitable conditions. As an application, we consider the computation of the Haezendonck risk measure of the sum of upper comonotonic random variables with exponential marginal distributions. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. Article Title: NONNESTED TESTING IN MODELS ESTIMATED VIA GENERALIZED METHOD OF MOMENTS
Abstract: We analyze the limiting distribution of the Rivers and Vuong (2002, Econometrics Journal 5, 1-39) statistic for choosing between two competing dynamic models based on a comparison of generalized method of moments minimands. It is shown that (i) if both models are misspecified then the statistic has a standard normal distribution under the null hypothesis of equal fit but the ranking could be determined by the choice of the weighting matrix; (ii) if both models are correctly specified or locally misspecified then the limiting distribution of the test statistic is nonstandard under the null.

Authors: Sendov, HS; Wang, Y; Zitikis, R
Author Full Names: Sendov, Hristo S.; Wang, Ying; Zitikis, Ricardas
Article Title: Log-supermodularity of weight functions, ordering weighted losses, and the loading monotonicity of weighted premiums
Author Keywords: Insurance premium; Weighted premium; Weighted distribution; Log-supermodularity; Supermodularity; Submodularity; Likelihood ratio order; Total positivity of order 2; Esscher premium; Conditional tail expectation; Kamps premium; Wang premium; Distortion premium; Decision under uncertainty
Abstract: The paper is motivated by a problem concerning the monotonicity of insurance premiums with respect to their loading parameter: the larger the parameter, the larger the insurance premium is expected to be. This property, usually called the loading monotonicity, is satisfied by premiums that appear in the literature. The increased interest in constructing new insurance premiums has raised a question as to what weight functions would produce loading-monotonic premiums. In this paper, we demonstrate a decisive role of log-supermodularity or, equivalently, of total positivity of order 2 (TP2) in answering this question. As a consequence, we establish - at a stroke - the loading monotonicity of a number of well-known insurance premiums, and offer a host of further weight functions, and consequently of premiums, thus illustrating the power of the herein suggested methodology for constructing loading-monotonic insurance premiums. (C) 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Disagreement point axioms and the egalitarian bargaining solution
Author Keywords: Bargaining; Egalitarian solution; Disagreement point monotonicity
Abstract: We provide new characterizations of the egalitarian bargaining solution on the class of strictly comprehensive n-person bargaining problems. The main axioms used in all of our results are Nash's IIA and disagreement point monotonicity-an axiom which requires a player's payoff to strictly increase in his disagreement payoff. For n = 2 these axioms, together with other standard requirements, uniquely characterize the egalitarian solution. For n > 2 we provide two extensions of our 2-person result, each of which is obtained by imposing an additional axiom on the solution. Dropping the axiom of anonymity, strengthening disagreement point monotonicity by requiring player i's payoff to be a strictly decreasing function of the disagreement payoff of every other player j not equal i, and adding a weak convexity axiom regarding changes of the disagreement point, we obtain a characterization of the class of weighted egalitarian solutions. This weak convexity axiom requires that a movement of the disagreement point in the direction of the solution point should not change the solution point. We also discuss the so-called transfer paradox and relate it to this axiom.

Authors: Beinhofer, M; Eberlein, E; Janssen, A; Polley, M
Author Full Names: Beinhofer, Maximilian; Eberlein, Ernst; Janssen, Arend; Polley, Manuel
Article Title: Correlations in Levy interest rate models
Author Keywords: Correlation structures; Correlation modelling; Interest rate modelling; Levy process; LIBOR market models; Fixed-income markets
Keywords Plus: TERM STRUCTURE MODELS; INVERSE GAUSSIAN DISTRIBUTIONS
Abstract: In a series of papers during the last ten years an interest rate theory with models which are driven by Levy or more general processes has been developed. In this paper we derive explicit formulas for the correlations of interest rates as well as zero coupon bonds with different maturities. The models considered in this general setting are the forward rate (HJM), the forward process and the LIBOR model as well as the multicurrency extension of the latter. Specific subclasses of the class of generalized hyperbolic Levy motions are studied as driving processes. Based on a data set of parametrized yield curves derived from German government bond prices we estimate correlations. In a second step the empirical correlations are used to calibrate the Levy forward rate model. The superior performance of the Levy driven models becomes obvious from the graphs.

Article Title: Simple regression-based tests for spatial dependence
Author Keywords: Heteroscedasticity; LM test; Spatial dependence
Keywords Plus: CLIFF-ORD TEST; AUTOCORRELATION; MODEL; HETEROSKEDASTICITY; BOOTSTRAP; POWER
Abstract: P>We propose simple and robust diagnostic tests for spatial error autocorrelation and spatial lag dependence. The idea is to reformulate the testing problem such that the outer product of gradients (OPG) variant of the LM test can be employed. Our versions of the tests are based on simple auxiliary regressions, where ordinary regression t- and F-statistics can be used to test for spatial autocorrelation and lag dependence. An important advantage of the proposed test statistics is that they are robust against heteroscedastic errors. Therefore, our approach gives practitioners an easy to implement and robust alternative to existing tests.

Authors: Bouvy, J; Weemers, J; Schellekens, H; Koopmanschap, M
Author Full Names: Bouvy, Jacoline; Weemers, Just; Schellekens, Huub; Koopmanschap, Marc
Article Title: Willingness to Pay for Adverse Drug Event Regulatory Actions
Keywords Plus: RED-CELL APLASIA; QUALITY-OF-LIFE; HEALTH-CARE; PUBLIC-GOODS; VALUATION; RISK; CALIBRATION; INNOVATION; ALTRUISM; THERAPY
Abstract: Background: Regulatory requirements for the pharmaceutical industry have become increasingly demanding with respect to the safety and effectiveness of drugs. Objective: The objective of this study was to determine the willingness to pay (WTP), of both the Dutch general public and dialysis patients, for regulatory requirements related to reducing the risk of pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) associated with epoetin alpha use. Methods: A survey was carried out in April 2009. The Dutch general public (n = 422) was approached through a survey sampling agency. Patients (n = 112) were included through several Dutch dialysis clinics because they are often treated with epoetin alpha and therefore were expected to have a higher WTP than the general public. The survey aimed to determine the WTP for reducing the risk of PRCA in epoetin alpha users from 4.5 to 0 per 10 000 patients per year, based on regulatory actions that have been taken by the European Medicines Agency (EMA). WTP was determined via a payment scale and an open-ended follow-up question. Patients were asked how much extra per year they would be willing to pay for their basic healthcare insurance. We used two censored regression models to test the association between WTP and a set of independent variables: a Tobit model with the stated WTP as the dependent variable and an interval regression model with the interval between the lower and upper bounds of the payment scale as the dependent variable. Results: The patients' mean WTP was significantly higher ((sic)46.52) than that of the general public ((sic)24.40). The Tobit model showed significant associations (alpha = 0.05) with WTP for dialysis patients, risk perception and respondents' opinions on costs of healthcare. The interval regression model showed significant associations with WTP for the same variables as the Tobit model and for one additional variable (risk aversion). Income did not significantly affect WTP. A scenario with a 10-fold larger risk reduction did not increase WTP significantly. Conclusion: This study is, as far as we know, one of the first attempts to analyse the WTP for drug regulation and should in future be used in studies of the societal costs of drug regulation for epoetin alpha use. Our results indicate that the Dutch general public, especially Dutch dialysis patients, are willing to pay limited amounts to reduce the risk of serious adverse events associated with drug use.

Author Full Names: Guy, Gery P., Jr.; Ekwueme, Donatus U.
Article Title: Years of Potential Life Lost and Indirect Costs of Melanoma and Non-Melanoma Skin Cancer A Systematic Review of the Literature
Keywords Plus: CUTANEOUS MALIGNANT-MELANOMA; UNITED-STATES; ECONOMIC-EVALUATION; ULTRAVIOLET-RADIATION; EPIDEMIOLOGY; BURDEN; TRENDS; ILLNESS; EUROPE; DERMATOLOGY
Abstract: Skin cancer is the most common form of cancer in the US, and an important public health concern both in the US and throughout the world. Given high incidence rates among young adults and the large number of deaths, skin cancer has the potential to result in significant years of potential life lost (YPLL) and lost productivity. The purpose of this study was to systematically review the published literature on the YPLL and the value of productivity loss from morbidity and premature mortality resulting from melanoma and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC). Employing pre-defined search terms and inclusion/exclusion criteria, systematic searches were conducted in MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL and Econlit. We selected studies that measured the societal burden of melanoma and NMSC through estimating either the YPLL and/or the indirect costs. We identified 16 relevant studies meeting our criteria, six were from the US and ten were from other industrialized countries; ten of the studies reported results on YPLL, eight on mortality costs and five on morbidity costs. Some studies reported results in more than one category. From each eligible article and report, we extracted detailed information on the study population/country, study design, data analysis methods and study results. Data abstracted for each eligible study included estimated number of YPLL, YPLL per death and morbidity and mortality costs. The average number of YPLL per death was approximately 15 for melanoma and 10 for NMSC. We found the costs attributable to melanoma and NMSC ranged from SUS39.2 million to $US28.9 million for morbidity and $US3.3 billion to $US1.0 billion for mortality, respectively. It is clear from the published literature that skin cancer leads to significant YPLL and indirect costs associated with premature mortality and morbidity. Prevention and early detection efforts are important in helping reduce the incidence of melanoma and NMSC, and the related deaths and productivity losses.

Article Title: Cost-Effectiveness Analysis of Prophylactic Lamivudine Use in Preventing Vertical Transmission of Hepatitis B Virus Infection
Keywords Plus: TERM-FOLLOW-UP; CHRONIC ACTIVE HEPATITIS; HEPATOCELLULAR-CARCINOMA; VIRAL-HEPATITIS; PERINATAL TRANSMISSION; VACCINATION PROGRAM; NATURAL-HISTORY; CARRIER STATE; DECOMPENSATED CIRRHOSIS; LIVER-TRANSPLANTATION
Abstract: Background: As neonates born to mothers with positive hepatitis B e antigen may not be completely protected by hepatitis B vaccination, prophylactic lamivudine use in mothers with high viraemia has been proposed. However, the overall effectiveness and the balance between cost and benefit for such a prophylactic strategy have rarely been addressed. Objective: Using a review of recent literature, we aimed to assess the cost effectiveness, from the Taiwanese societal perspective, of administering prophylactic lamivudine to mothers to reduce vertical transmission of hepatitis B virus and its long-term sequelae in neonates. Methods: A meta-analysis of three randomized controlled trials was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of lamivudine versus placebo. A Markov decision model was constructed in which in both treatment arms infants received active and passive immunoprophylaxis. An economic evaluation was performed to calculate costs, acute infections averted, and QALYs gained. Probabilistic sensitivity analyses were conducted and a cost-effectiveness acceptability curve drawn. All these analyses were from the societal perspective. Costs (SUS) were valued in year 2008 prices. Result: Supplemental lamivudine use gained an additional 0.0024 QALYs and averted 0.23 acute infections per birth compared with the routine active-passive immunization without lamivudine. The cost-effectiveness analysis suggested that the use of additional prophylactic lamivudine dominated the routine strategy. The acceptability curve suggested that the probability of being cost effective under the willingness-to-pay threshold of $US20 000 was 94%. Conclusion: This analysis suggests that supplemental use of lamivudine in mothers with high hepatitis B viraemia is effective in reducing vertical transmission and may be cost effective, from a Taiwanese societal perspective, compared with the routine active-passive immunization without lamivudine.

Article Title: Calibrating Models in Economic Evaluation A Comparison of Alternative Measures of Goodness of Fit, Parameter Search Strategies and Convergence Criteria
Keywords Plus: NATURAL-HISTORY MODEL; COST-UTILITY ANALYSIS; MEDICATION ERROR; BREAST-CANCER; TAMOXIFEN
Abstract: Background: The importance of assessing the accuracy of health economic decision models is widely recognized. Many applied decision models (implicitly) assume that the process of identifying relevant values for a model's input parameters is sufficient to prove the model's accuracy. The selection of infeasible combinations of input parameter values is most likely in the context of probabilistic sensitivity analysis (PSA), where parameter values are drawn from independently specified probability distributions for each model parameter. Model calibration involves the identification of input parameter values that produce model output parameters that best predict observed data. Methods: An empirical comparison of three key calibration issues is presented: the applied measure of goodness of fit (GOF), the search strategy for selecting sets of input parameter values; and the convergence criteria for determining acceptable GOF. The comparisons are presented in the context of probabilistic calibration, a widely applicable approach to calibration that can be easily integrated with PSA. The appendix provides a user's guide to probabilistic calibration, with the reader invited to download the Microsoft (R) Excel-based model reported in this article. Results: The calibrated models consistently provided higher mean estimates of the models' output parameter, illustrating the potential gain in accuracy derived from calibrating decision models. Model uncertainty was also reduced. The chi-squared GOF measure differentiated between the accuracy of different parameter sets to a far greater degree than the likelihood GOF measure. The guided search strategy produced higher mean estimates of the models' output parameter, as well as a narrower range of predicted output values, which may reflect greater precision in the identification of candidate parameter sets or more limited coverage of the parameter space. The broader convergence threshold resulted in lower mean estimates of the models' output, and slightly wider ranges, which were closer to the outputs associated with the non-calibrated approach. Conclusions: Probabilistic calibration provides a broadly applicable method that will improve the relevance of health economic decision models, and simultaneously reduce model uncertainty. The analyses reported in this paper inform the more efficient and accurate application of calibration methods for health economic decision models.

Article Title: A Consistent Test for Multivariate Conditional Distributions
Author Keywords: Absolutely regular process; Consistent test; Degenerate U-statistics; Stochastic differential equation
Abstract: We propose a new test for a multivariate parametric conditional distribution of a vector of variables yt given a conditional vector xt. The proposed test is shown to have an asymptotic normal distribution under the null hypothesis, while being consistent for all fixed alternatives, and having nontrivial power against a sequence of local alternatives. Monte Carlo simulations show that our test has reasonable size and good power for both univariate and multivariate models, even for highly persistent dependent data with sample sizes often encountered in empirical finance.

Article Title: The Hausman test in a Cliff and Ord panel model
Author Keywords: Hausman test; Panel data; Random effects estimator; Spatial econometrics; Within estimator
Abstract: This paper studies the random effects model and the fixed effects model for spatial panel data. The model includes a Cliff and Ord type spatial lag of the dependent variable as well as a spatially lagged one-way error component structure, accounting for both heterogeneity and spatial correlation across units. We discuss instrumental variable estimation under both the fixed and the random effects specifications and propose a spatial Hausman test which compares these two models accounting for spatial autocorrelation in the disturbances. We derive the large sample properties of our estimation procedures and show that the test statistic is asymptotically chi-square distributed. A small Monte Carlo study demonstrates that this test works well even in small panels.

Article Title: Optimal incentive contracts under relative income concerns
Author Keywords: Multi-agent problems; Hidden action; Envy; Jealousy; Behavioral Contract Theory; Optimal effort; Pay-for-performance sensitivity
Abstract: We are studying in this article an interplay between workers in organizations under the assumption that workers exhibit behavioral biases: envy, jealousy, or admiration toward the other coworkers' compensation. We assume workers care about their relative position, and we study the impact of this assumption on their efforts and on their optimal incentive contracts. We explicitly solve for the optimal incentive contract of moral hazard a la Holmstrom and Milgrom (Econometrica 55:303-328, 1987). We model team production by agents in which each agent's effort generates an observable signal and depends on efforts of other agents. One of the important findings is that an agent's optimal effort is negatively impacted by the behavioral biases in other agents' judgments. We also show envious behavior is destructive for organizations. Consistent with Tirole (Econometrica 69(1):1-35, 2001), our findings suggest that in the presence of agency problems induced by envy or jealousy, the optimal compensation exhibits high pay-for-performance sensitivity.

Article Title: BIAS CORRECTIONS IN TESTING AND ESTIMATING SEMIPARAMETRIC, SINGLE INDEX MODELS
Abstract: Semiparametric methods are widely employed in applied work where the ability to conduct inferences is important. To establish asymptotic normality for making inferences, bias control mechanisms are often used in implementing semiparametric estimators. The first contribution of this paper is to propose a mechanism that enables us to establish asymptotic normality with regular kernels. In so doing, we argue that the resulting estimator performs very well in finite samples. Semiparametric models are commonly estimated under a single index assumption. Because the consistency of the estimator critically depends on this assumption being correct, our second objective is to develop a test for it. To ensure that the test statistic has good size and power properties in finite samples, we employ a bias control mechanism similar to that underlying the estimator. Furthermore, we structure the test so that its form adapts to the model under the alternative hypothesis. Monte Carlo results confirm that the bias control and the adaptive feature significantly improve the performance of the test statistic in finite samples.

Article Title: LOCAL RANK ESTIMATION OF TRANSFORMATION MODELS WITH FUNCTIONAL COEFFICIENTS
Keywords Plus: SEMIPARAMETRIC ESTIMATION; UNKNOWN TRANSFORMATION; REGRESSION-MODEL; INDEX MODELS; U-PROCESSES
Abstract: This paper considers a nonparametric functional coefficient model with an unknown link function. The model gives flexibility to the standard interaction-variable model by allowing an arbitrary functional form of heterogeneous marginal effects. A local rank estimation procedure is proposed for the functional coefficients along with its asymptotic property.
